atenção questões números 1 11 referemse texto segueno livro human nature in politics publicado 1908 deputado inglês graham wallas criticou tendência época difundida imaginar políticos pudessem encarnar padrão racionalidade devoção bem comum virtude cívica postulado filósofos século xviii políticos – escreveu – representam natureza humana defeitos qualidades menoswallas primeiro destacar fosso abrira política real desenrola parlamento noutros órgãos estado percepção parte opinião pública fato iluminismo criara noção psicologicamente superficial cidadão filosofante nada ver cidadãos carne osso reflexões realistas sobre tal discrepância demoraram aparecer wallas tendo sido pioneira instiganteshoje sabemos fenômeno descrito wallas especificamente inglês passageiro apareceu reação disfunções características estágios iniciais democracia representativa questionamentos semelhantes continuam manifestar toda parte duas vertentes nitidamente diferenciadas notou referente atitudes cidadão comum relação funcionamento instituições sobretudo legislativos partidos políticos outra propriamente filosófica refere ideologia liberal mundo modernoo azedume primeira vertente sido regularmente pesquisado entidades acadêmicas todo mundo difícil dizer existe consenso quanto causa formas características antídotos administrados eficácia duvidosa têm sido basicamente reformas institucionais concentrandose principalmente sistemas partidários eleitorais tudo faz crer cidadão comum quer ordem quer estado capaz mantêla deseja diluição destruição poder menos experiências anar quistas tresloucadas despreza “ política ” sentido comumente atribuído termo hesitaria acabar soubesse fazêlo valoriza finalidade última estado abomina meio atua sistema políticona raiz desse sentimento parece fator psicológico – desconforto cidadão comum diante certas exterioridades política cujas funções chega compreender bem luta políticos controle partidos chapas elei torais labirinto táticas combate parlamentar retórica quase sempre entediante caráter vago francamente inexequível maioria promessas feitas durante campanhas outrasa segunda vertente nutrese ideias filosóficas estéticas abrangentes radicais formouse bojo grandes transformações lugar europa desde século xviii base materiais sociedade revolução industrial conflito class esfera estado direito transição absolutismo estado constitucional plano cultura arte chamada “ idade ideologia ” advento romantismo sob decisivo influxo obra jeanjacques rousseauconsidere parágrafo final texto acima reproduzido contexto inserido leia atenção afirmações seguir indicadas deduções texto permitiria acerca segunda vertentepoderia ter pretensão erradicar instituições políticas existentes mundo social cultural conhecidopoderia levando conta citado desconforto cidadão comum ter pretensão romper opacidade instituições política exemplo modo fazer prevalecer transparência ações intençõesteria ambição encarnar padrão racionalidade devoção bem comum virtude cívica postulado filósofos século xviii políticos – escreveu – representam natureza humana defeitos qualidades menoswallas primeiro destacar fosso abrira política real desenrola parlamento noutros órgãos estado percepção parte opinião pública fato iluminismo criara noção psicologicamente superficial cidadão filosofante nada ver cidadãos carne osso reflexões realistas sobre tal discrepância demoraram aparecer wallas tendo sido pioneira instiganteshoje sabemos fenômeno descrito wallas especificamente inglês passageiro apareceu reação described by asperger in 1938 and kanner in 1943 is severe neurodevelopmental disorder and belongs to autism spectrum disorder asds including autism asperger syndrome rett syndrome unidentified pervasive developmental disorder and childhood disintegrative disorder cdd autism is four to five time more common among boy than girl the most prominent clinical and phenotypic feature of autism are extensive disability in social and behavioral communication language impairment or inability to speak and strong tendency toward stereotyped and repetitive pattern of behavior regarding statistical report the prevalence of autism had increased from 45 case per 10000 child in 1980s to 30–60 case in 1990s and through an astonishing increase there are about 80 per 1000 child aged 8 year in 2004 and 90 per 1000 in 2006 or 1 in every 110 child aged 8 year in 2006 in 2012 combined asd prevalence of 113 per 1000 child aged 8 year or 1 in 88 child wa published by the autism and developmental disability monitoring network with regard to it progressive increase over the last two decade and lack of effective treatment and moreover the difficulty imposed on the society and family of autistic child importance of investigation on cause of this disease and an effort to prevent it become clear study of identical twin and lack of complete concordance among them and excessive genetic study with conclusive result unveil the importance of environmental risk factor and their role in the etiology of autism hence the interaction between susceptible gene and environmental factor have been proposed the major mechanism of autism etiologynone of the environmental factor however is sufficient to yield autism but rather collection of them can be involved in it incidence these can be divided into prenatal natal and postnatal risk factorsadvanced parental age particularly paternal age ha been identified one of the most important prenatal risk factor of autism in many study maternal and paternal age older than or equal to 34 year ha been found associated with increased risk of autism in their offspring however in other study the relationship between child autism and the age of both parent or even the age of one parent is rejected intriguingly the relationship between increased risk of autism and elevated paternal age ha been approved in most study particularly study wa conducted among iranian people in 2010 to explore the presence or absence of association between parental age and risk of autism based on this study autism risk increase by 29 every 10year elevation in father ’ age in other word father aged between 34 and 39 had nearly twofold greater risk and those who are older than 40 have more than twofold 258 greater risk to have an affected child in comparison to one aged 2529 year old in other study in japan and china similar relationship were explored between paternal age and increased risk of autism lack of any correlation between maternal age and susceptibility of autism in these three mentioned study ha critical importancestudies involving maternal age have shown that being small gestational age can increase the risk of autism due to lack of physical maturity inability and poor maternal care mother who are younger than 20 may be exposed to intrauterine growth retardation of fetus and preterm birth which are both associated with increased risk of autismadapted from journal of research in medical sciences2017 2227studies have confirmed that

atenção responder questões números 79 80 considere texto abaixoneurobionics and the braincomputer interface current application and future horizonsrosenfeld jv wong ytthe braincomputer interface bci is an exciting advance in neuroscience and engineering in motor bci electrical recording from the motor cortex of paralysed human are decoded by computer and used to drive robotic arm or to restore movement in paralysed hand by stimulating the muscle in the forearm simultaneously integrating bci with the sensory cortex will further enhance dexterity and fine control bcis are also being developed to provide ambulation paraplegic patient through controlling robotic exoskeleton restore vision in people with acquired blindness detect and control epileptic seizure and improve control of movement disorder and memory enhancement highfidelity connectivity with small group of neuron requires microelectrode placement the cerebral cortex electrode placed on the cortical surface are le invasive but produce inferior fidelity scalp surface recording using electroencephalography is much le precise bci technology is still in an early phase of development and awaits further technical improvement and larger multicentre clinical trial before wider clinical application and impact on the care of people with disability there are also many ethical challenge to explore this technology evolves inethical and practical considerationsimplantable bci device are in an early phase of development with most firstinhuman study describing only single patient however the performance of these device is rapidly improving and they become wireless the next step will be to implant bcis in larger number of patient in multicentre trialsthe prime purpose of neurobionic device is to help people with disability however there will be pressure in the future bionic enhancement of normal cognitive memory sensory or motor function using bcis memory augmentation cognitive enhancement infrared vision and exoskeletal enhancement of physical performance will all likely be achievablethe introduction of this technology generates many ethical challenge including− appreciation of the riskbenefit ratio− provision of adequate and balanced information the recipient to give informed consent− affordability in relation to the fair and equitable use of the scarce health dollar− inequality of patient access to implant particularly affecting those in poorer countries− undue influence on physician and scientist by commercial interest and− the ability to achieve unfair physical or cognitive advantage with the technology such enhancing disabled athlete ’ performance using exoskeleton device military application with the creation of an enhanced “ super ” soldier or using bci the ultimate lie detector trial to transition from clinicalthe introduction of these device into clinical practice should therefore not proceed unchecked the technology the marketplace training course and mentoring will be needed the surgeon who are implanting these device any new human application of the bci should be initially tested safety and efficacy in experimental animal model after receiving ethic committee approval human application the technology should be thoroughly evaluated in well conducted clinical trial with clear protocol and strict inclusion criteriaadapted from medical journal of australia leia texto responder questões 38 45poverty may hinder kid ’ brain development study saysreduced gray matter lower test score reported poor childrenjuly 20 2015poverty appears to affect the brain development of child hampering the growth of gray matter and impairing their academic performance researcher report poor child tend to have much 10 percent le gray matter in several area of the brain associated with academic skill according to study published july 20 in jama pediatrics “ we used to think of poverty ‘ social ’ issue but what we are learning now is that it is biomedical issue that is affecting brain growth ” said senior study author seth pollak professor of psychology pediatrics anthropology and neuroscience at the university of wisconsinmadisonthe result could have profound implication the united state where lowincome student now represent the majority of kid in public school the study author said in background information fiftyone percent of public school student came from lowincome family in 2013previous study have shown that child living in poverty tend to perform poorly in school the author say they have markedly lower test score and not go far in school their welloff peersto see whether this is due to some physical effect that poverty might have on child ’ s brain pollak and his colleague analyzed mri scan of 389 typically developing kid aged 4 to 22 assessing the amount of gray matter in the whole brain well the frontal lobe temporal lobe and hippocampus “ gray matter contains most of the brain ’ s neuronal cell ” pollak said “ in other word other part of the brain – like white matter – carry information from one section of the brain to another but the gray matter is where seeing and hearing memory emotion speech decision making and selfcontrol occur ” child living below 150 percent of the federal poverty level – u 36375 family of four – had 3 percent to 4 percent le gray matter in important region of their brain compared to the is u 24250 family of four these same kid scored an average of four to seven point lower on standardized test the researcher saidthe team estimated that much 20 percent of the gap in test score could factor related to impoverishment such high stress level poor sleep crowding and poor nutrition pollak saidthis study serf call to action given what ’ s already known about the effect of poverty on it ’ s perilous time to be statue not that it ha ever been particularly secure occupation exposed statue are to the element bird droppings and political windsjust ask queen victoria whose rounded frame perch atop hundred of plinth across the commonwealth with an air of solemn severe solidity but in 1963 in quebec member of separatist paramilitary group stuck dynamite under the dress of her local statue it exploded with force so great that her head wa found 100 yard awaytoday the head is on display in museumwith her body preserved in room some mile away the art historian vincent giguère said that “ the fact it ’ s damaged is what make it so important ” there ’ s another reason to conserve the beheaded victoria statue of woman standing alone and demanding attention in public space are extremely rareto be made statue woman had to be naked muse royalty or the mother of god or occasionally an icon of war justice or virtue boadicea in her chariot in london the statue of liberty in new yorkstill of 925 public statue in britain only 158 are woman standing on their own of those 110 are allegorical or mythical and 29 are of queen victoriajulia baird the new york time september 4 2017 adaptadono texto referência número estátuas expostas espaços públicos grãbretanha indica

leia texto responder questões 11a 20can plant hearflora may be able to detect thesounds of flowing water or munching insectspseudoscientific claim that music help plant grow have been made decade despite evidence that is shaky at best yet new research suggests some flora may be capable of sensing sound such the gurgle of water through pipe or the buzzing of insectsin recent study monica gagliano an evolutionary biologist at the university of western australia and her colleague placed pea seedling in pot shaped like an upsidedown y one arm of each pot wa placed in either tray of water or coiled plastic tube through which water flowed the other arm had dry soil the root grew toward the arm of the pipe with the fluid regardless of whether it wa easily accessible or hidden inside the tubing “ they just knew the water wa there even if the only thing to detect wa the sound of it flowing inside the pipe ” gagliano say yet when the seedling were given choice between the water tube and some moistened soil their root favored the latter she hypothesizes that these plant use sound wave to detect water at distance but follow moisture gradient to home in on their target when it is closerthe research reported earlier this year in oecologia is not the first to suggest flora can detect and interpret sound 2014 study showed the rock cress arabidopsis can distinguish between caterpillar chewing sound and wind vibration – the plant produced more chemical toxin after “ hearing ” recording of feeding insect “ we tend to underestimate plant because their response are usually le visible to u but leaf turn out to be extremely sensitive vibration detector ” say lead study author heidi m appel an environmental scientist now at the university of toledomarta zaraska wwwscientificamericancom 17052017de acordo ideias apresentadas texto frase contém ideia suposição

brasileiro forma ordinária convívio social fundo justamente contrário polidez pode iludir aparência — explica fato atitude polida consistir precisamente espécie mímica deliberada manifestações espontâneas “ homem cordial ” forma natural viva converteu fórmula além disso polidez algum modo organização defesa ante sociedade detémse parte exterior epidérmica indivíduo podendo servir necessário peça resistência equivale disfarce permitirá cada preservar intatas sensibilidade emoçõespor meio semelhante padronização formas exteriores cordialidade precisam legítimas manifestarem revelase decisivo triunfo espírito sobre vida armado dessa máscara indivíduo consegue manter supremacia ante social efetivamente polidez implica presença contínua soberana indivíduono “ homem cordial ” vida healthy choiceshow we reduce waistline in country wherewe traditionally not like telling individual what todoby telegraph vtew22aug 2014duncan selbie the chief executive of public healthengland suggests that parent feed their childrenfrom smaller plate photo alamyevery new piece of information about britain ’ s weight problem make ever more depressing reading duncan selbie the chief executive of public health england today tell u that by 2034 some six million briton will suffer from diabetes of course many people develop diabetes through fault of their own but mr selbie ’ s research concludes that if the level of obesity returned to their 1994 level 17 million fewer people would suffer from conditiongiven that fighting diabetes already drain the national health service nh by more than £15 million or 10 per cent of it budget england the impact upon the treasury in 20 year ’ time from unhealthy lifestyle could be catastrophic bad health not only impact on the individual but also on the rest of the communitydiagnosis of the challenge is straightforward the tougher question is what to about reducing waistline in country where we traditionally not like telling individual what to doit is interesting to note that mr selbie doe not ascribe to the big brother approach of ceaseless legislation and nannying rather he is keen to promote choice – making the case passionately that people should be encouraged to embrace good health one of his suggestion is that parent feed their child from smaller plate that way the child can clear his or her plate ordered without actually consuming too much like all good idea this is rooted in common sensewwwtelegraphcouk adaptadosegundo texto diabetes

leia texto responder questões 37 44why so few nurse are menask health professional in any country what the biggest problem in their healthcare system is and one of the most common answer is the shortage of nurse in ageing rich country demand nursing care is becoming increasingly insatiable britain ’ s national health service example ha 40000odd nurse vacancy poor country struggle with the emigration of nurse greener pasture one obvious solution seems neglected recruit more men typically just 510 of nurse registered in given country are men why so fewviews of nursing “ woman ’ s job ” have deep root florence nightingale who established the principle of modern nursing in the 1860s insisted that men ’ s “ hard and horny ” hand were “ not fitted to touch bathe and dress wounded limb ” in britain the royal college of nursing the profession ’ s union did not even admit men member until 1960 some nursing school in america started admitting men only in 1982 after supreme court ruling forced them to senior nurse title such “ sister ” ward manager and “ matron ” which in some country is used men well not help matter unsurprisingly some older people not even know that men can be nurse too male nurse often encounter patient who assume they are doctorsanother problem is that belief about what nursing job entail are often outdated – in way that may be particularly offputting men in film nurse are commonly portrayed the helper of heroic male doctor in fact nurse most of their work independently and are the first responder to patient in crisis to dispel myth nurserecruitment campaign display nursing professional job with career progression specialism like anaesthetic cardiology or emergency care and use skill related to technology innovation and leadership however attracting men without playing to gender stereotype can be tricky “ are you man enough to be nurse ” the slogan of an american campaign wa involved in controversynursing is not career many boy aspire to or are encouraged to consider only twofifths of british parent say they would be proud if their son became nurse because of all this men who go into nursing are usually already closely familiar with the job some are following in the career footstep of their mother others decide that the job would suit them after they see male nurse care relative or they themselves get care from male nurse when hospitalised although many gender stereotype about job and caring have crumbled nursing ha so far remained unaffectedwwweconomistcom 22082018 adaptadono trecho primeiro parágrafo “ poor country leia texto responder questões números 39 45the rise of antibiotic resistanceby the editorial boardmay 10 2014the world health organization ha surveyed the growth of antibioticresistant germ around world – the first such survey it ha ever conducted – and come up with disturbing finding ln report issued late last month the organization found that antimicrobial resistance in bacteria the main focus of the report fungi virus and parasite is an increasingly serious threat in every part of the world “ problem so serious that it threatens the achievement ofmodern medicine ” the organization said “ postantibiotic in which common infection and minor injury can kill far from being an apocalyptic fantasy is instead very real possibility the 21st century ” the growth of antibioticresistant pathogen mean that in ever more case standard treatment longer work infection are harder or impossible to control the risk of spreading infection to others is increased and illness and hospital stay are prolonged ali of these drive up the cost of illness and the risk of dealh the survey sought to determine the scope of the problem by asking country to submit their most recent surveillance data 114 did so unfortunately the data wa glaringly incomplete because few country track and monitor antibiotic resistance comprehensively and there is standard methodology doing sostill it is clear that major resistance problem have already developed both antibiotic that are used routinely and those deemed “ last resort ” treatrnents to cure people when all else ha failed carbapenem antibiotic class of drug used last resort to treat lifethreatening infection caused by common intestinal bacterium have failed to work in more than half the people treated in some country the bacterium is major cause of hospitalacquired infection such pneumonia bloodstream infection and infection in newborn and intensivecare patient similarly the failure of lastresort treatment gonorrhoea ha been confirmed in 10 country including many with advanced health care system such australia canada france sweden and britain and resistance to class of antibiotic that is routinely used to treat urinary tract infection caused by coli is widespread in some country the drug are now ineffective in more than half of the patient treated this sobering report is intended to kickstart global campaign to develop tool and standard to track drug resistance measure it health and economic impact and design solutionsthe most urgent need is to minimize the overuse of antibiotic in medicine and agriculture which accelerates the development of resistant strain in the united state the food and drug administration fda ha issued voluntary guideline calling on drug company animal producer and veterinarian to stop indiscriminately using antibiotic that are important treating human on livestock the drug company have said they will comply but the agency shortsightedly ha appealed court order requiring it to ban the use of penicillin and two form of tetracycline by animal producer to promote growth unless they provide proof that il will not promote drugresistant microbesthe pharmaceutical industry need to be encouraged to develop new antibiotic to supplement those that are losing their effectiveness the royal pharmaceutical society which represents pharmacist in britain called this month stronger financial incentive it said that new class of antibiotic ha been discovered since 1987 largely because the financial return finding new class of antibiotic are too low unlike lucrative drug to treat chronic disease like cancer and cardiovascular ailment antibiotic are typically taken short period of time and any new drug is apt to be used sparingly and held in reserve to treat patient resistant to existing drug antibiotic have transformed medicine and saved countless life over the past seven decade now rampant overuse and the lack of new drug in the pipeline threaten to undermine their effectivenesswwwnytimes adaptadosegundo texto objetivos relatório organização mundial saúde

healthy choiceshow we reduce waistline in country wherewe traditionally not like telling individual what to doby telegraph vtew22aug 2014duncan selbie the chief executive of public health england suggests that parent feed their child from smaller plate photo alamyevery new piece of information about britain ’ s weight problem make ever more depressing reading duncan selbie the chief executive of public health england today tell u that by 2034 some six million briton will suffer from diabetes of course many people develop diabetes through fault of their own but mr selbie ’ s research concludes that if the level of obesity returned to their 1994 level 17 million fewer people would suffer from the conditiongiven that fighting diabetes already drain the national health service nh by more than £15 million or 10 per cent of it budget england the impact upon the treasury in 20 year ’ time from unhealthy lifestyle could be catastrophic bad health not only impact on the individual but also on the rest of the communitydiagnosis of the challenge is straightforward the tougher question is what to about reducing waist line in country where we traditionally not like telling individual what to doit is interesting to note that mr selbie doe not ascribeto the big brother approach of ceaseless legislation and nannying rather he is keen to promote choice – making the case passionately that people should be encouraged to embrace good health one of his suggestion is that parent feed their child from smaller plate that way the child can clear his or her plate ordered without actually consuming too much like all good idea this is rooted in common sensewwwtelegraphcouk adaptadono trecho segundo parágrafo “ bad health not only impact on the individual but also on the rest of the community ” expressão “ not only … but also ” indica ideia

leia trecho inicial raízes brasil historiador brasileiro sérgio buarque holanda 19021982 responder questões 02 07a tentativa implantação cultura europeia extenso território dotado condições naturais adversas largamente estranhas tradição milenar origen sociedade brasileira fato dominante rico consequências trazendo países distantes formas convívio instituições ideias timbrando manter tudo ambiente muitas vezes desfavorável hostil ainda hoje un desterrados terra podemos construir obras excelentes enriquecer humanidade aspectos novos imprevistos elevar perfeição tipo civilização representamos certo todo fruto trabalho preguiça parece participar sistema evolução próprio outro clima outra paisagemassim ante perguntar ponto poderá alcançar bom êxito tentativa caberia averiguar onde podido representar formas convívio instituições ideias herdeirosé significativa primeiro lugar circunstância termos recebido herança através nação ibérica espanha portugal rússia países balcânicos certo sentido inglaterra territóriosponte quais europa comunica outros mundos assim constituem zona fronteiriça transição menos carregada alguns casos desse europeísmo obstante mantêm patrimônio necessáriofoi partir época grandes descobrimentos marítimos doi países entraram decididamente coro europeu ingresso tardio deveria repercutir intensamente destinos determinando muitos aspectos peculiares história formação espiritual surgiu assim tipo sociedade desenvolveria alguns sentidos quase margem congêneres europeias receber qualquer incitamento trouxesse germequais fundamentos assentam preferência formas vida social nessa região indecisa europa áfrica estende pireneus gibraltar explicar muitas daquelas formas recorrer indicações menos vagas jamais conduziriam estrita objetividadeprecisamente comparação europa alémpireneus faz ressaltar característica bem peculiar gente península ibérica característica longe partilhar menos mesma intensidade qualquer vizinhos continente nenhum des vizinhos soube desenvolver tal extremo cultura personalidade parece constituir traço decisivo evolução gente hispânica desde tempo imemoriais pode dizerse realmente importância particular atribuem valor próprio pessoa humana autonomia cada homens relação semelhantes tempo espaço devem espanhóis portuguese originalidade nacional resulta largamente singular tibieza formas organização toda associações impliquem solidariedade ordenação povos terra onde todos barões possível acordo coletivo durável força exterior respeitável temidaraízes brasil 2000no primeiro parágrafo autor recorre construção paradoxal

leia texto responder questões 38 45poverty may hinder kid ’ brain development study saysreduced gray matter lower test score reported poor childrenjuly 20 2015poverty appears to affect the brain development of child hampering the growth of gray matter and impairing their academic performance researcher report poor child tend to have much 10 percent le gray matter in several area of the brain associated with academic skill according to study published july 20 in jama pediatrics “ we used to think of poverty ‘ social ’ issue but what we are learning now is that it is biomedical issue that is affecting brain growth ” said senior study author seth pollak professor of psychology pediatrics anthropology and neuroscience at the university of wisconsinmadisonthe result could have profound implication the united state where lowincome student now represent the majority of kid in public school the study author said in background information fiftyone percent of public school student came from lowincome family in 2013previous study have shown that child living in poverty tend to perform poorly in school the author say they have markedly lower test score and not go far in school their welloff peersto see whether this is due to some physical effect that poverty might have on child ’ s brain pollak and his colleague analyzed mri scan of 389 typically developing kid aged 4 to 22 assessing the amount of gray matter in the whole brain well the frontal lobe temporal lobe and hippocampus “ gray matter contains most of the brain ’ s neuronal cell ” pollak said “ in other word other part of the brain – like white matter – carry information from one section of the brain to another but the gray matter is where seeing and hearing memory emotion speech decision making and selfcontrol occur ” child living below 150 percent of the federal poverty level – u 36375 family of four – had 3percent to 4 percent le gray matter in important region of their brain compared to the norm the author found those in family living below the federal poverty level fared even worse with 8 percent to 10 percent le gray matter in those same brain region the federal poverty level in 2015 is u 24250 family of four these same kid scored an average of four to seven point lower on standardized test the researcher saidthe team estimated that much 20 percent of the gap in test score could be explained by reduced brain development host of povertyrelated issue likely contribute to developmental lag in child ’ s brain pollak said lowincome kid are le likely to get the type of stimulation from their parent and environment that help the brain grow he said example they hear fewer new word and have fewer opportunity to read or play game their brain development also can be affected by factor related to impoverishment such high stress level poor sleep crowding and poor nutrition pollak saidthis study serf call to action given what ’ s already known about the effect of poverty on child development said dr joan luby professor of child psychiatry at washington university school of medicine in st louis “ the thing that ’ s really important about this study in the context of the broader literature is that there really is enough scientific evidence to take public health action at this point ” said luby who wrote an editorial accompanying the study “ poverty negatively affect brain development and we also know that early intervention are powerfully effective ” luby said “ they are more effective than intervention later in life and they also are costeffective ” wwwnlmnihgov adaptadoos estudos anteriores pesquisa liderada dr seth pollak evidenciam

leia excerto crônica “ mineirinho ” clarice lispector 19251977 publicada revista senhor 1962 responder questões 25 30é suponho mim representantes devo procurar doendo morte facínora1 adianta contar treze tiro mataram mineirinho2 crime perguntei cozinheira pensava sobre assunto vi rosto pequena convulsão conflito malestar entender sente precisar trair sensações contraditórias saber harmonizálas fatos irredutíveis revolta irredutível violenta compaixão revolta sentirse dividido própria perplexidade diante poder esquecer mineirinho perigoso matara demais entanto queríamos vivo cozinheira fechou pouco vendome talvez justiça vinga alguma raiva mim mexendo alma respondeu fria “ sinto serve dizer sabe mineirinho criminoso certeza salvou entrou céu ” respondilhe “ muita gente matou ” quê entanto primeira lei protege corpo vida insubstituíveis matarás maior garantia assim matam porque quero morrer assim deixam matar porque ter matado escuridão mimesta lei alguma coisa faz ouvir primeiro segundo tiro alívio segurança terceiro deixa alerta quarto desassossegada quinto sexto cobrem vergonha sétimo oitavo ouço coração batendo horror nono décimo boca trêmula décimo primeiro digo espanto nome deus décimo segundo chamo irmão décimo terceiro tiro assassina — porque outro porque quero outroessa justiça vela sono repudio humilhada precisar enquanto durmo falsamente salvo sonsos essenciais casa funcione exijo mim primeiro dever sonsa exerça revolta amor guardados sonsa casa estremece devo ter esquecido embaixo casa terreno chão onde nova casa poderia erguida enquanto dormimos falsamente salvamos treze tiro acordam horror digo tarde demais – vinte oito ano mineirinho nasceu – homem acuado matem porque sei erro vida inteira deus salva vezes apenas erro sei salvaremos enquanto erro precioso erro espelho onde vejo silêncio fiz homem erro modo vi vida abrir carne espantei vi matéria vida placenta sangue lama viva mineirinho rebentou modo viverclarice lispector esquecer 19991 facínora dizse indivíduo executa crime crueldade perversidade acentuada2 mineirinho apelido conhecido criminoso carioca josé miranda rosa acuado polícia acabou crivado balas corpo leia trecho inicial raízes brasil historiador brasileiro sérgio buarque holanda 19021982 responder questões 02 07a tentativa implantação cultura europeia extenso território dotado condições naturais adversas largamente estranhas tradição milenar origen sociedade brasileira fato dominante rico consequências trazendo países distantes formas convívio instituições ideias timbrando manter tudo ambiente muitas vezes desfavorável hostil ainda hoje un desterrados terra podemos construir obras excelentes enriquecer humanidade aspectos novos imprevistos elevar perfeição tipo civilização representamos certo todo fruto trabalho preguiça parece participar sistema evolução próprio outro clima outra paisagemassim ante perguntar ponto poderá alcançar bom êxito tentativa caberia averiguar onde podido representar formas convívio instituições ideias herdeirosé significativa primeiro lugar circunstância termos recebido herança através nação ibérica espanha portugal rússia países balcânicos certo sentido inglaterra territóriosponte quais europa comunica outros mundos assim constituem zona fronteiriça transição menos carregada alguns casos desse europeísmo obstante mantêm patrimônio necessáriofoi partir época grandes descobrimentos marítimos doi países entraram decididamente coro europeu ingresso tardio deveria repercutir intensamente destinos determinando muitos aspectos peculiares história formação espiritual surgiu assim tipo sociedade desenvolveria alguns sentidos quase margem congêneres europeias receber qualquer incitamento trouxesse germequais fundamentos assentam preferência formas vida social nessa região indecisa europa áfrica estende pireneus gibraltar explicar muitas daquelas formas recorrer indicações menos vagas jamais conduziriam estrita objetividadeprecisamente comparação europa alémpireneus faz ressaltar característica bem peculiar gente península ibérica característica longe partilhar menos mesma intensidade qualquer vizinhos continente nenhum des vizinhos soube desenvolver tal extremo cultura personalidade parece constituir traço decisivo evolução gente hispânica desde tempo imemoriais pode dizerse realmente importância particular atribuem valor próprio pessoa humana autonomia cada homens relação semelhantes tempo espaço devem espanhóis portuguese originalidade nacional resulta largamente singular tibieza formas organização toda associações impliquem solidariedade ordenação povos terra onde todos barões possível acordo coletivo durável força exterior respeitável temidaraízes brasil 2000em “ resulta largamente singular tibieza formas organização toda associações impliquem solidariedade ordenação povos ” 7° parágrafo termo destacado pode substituído prejuízo sentido texto

pânico – tristíssimo pormenor – cadáver comandante defenderam breve simulacro repulsa contra inimigo viam adivinhavam estrídulo gritos desafiadores estampidos tiroteio irregular escasso caçada primeiros tiro batalhões diluíramseapenas artilharia extremum retaguarda seguia vagarosa unida solene quase marcha habitual revista parava varrer disparos macegas traiçoeiras prosseguindo lentamente rodando inabordável terrívelum tombavam soldados guarnição estoica feridos espantados muares tração empacavam torciam rumo impossibilitavam marchaa bateria afinal parou canhões emperrados imobilizaramse volta caminhoo coronel tamarindo volvera retaguarda agitandose destemeroso infatigável fugitivos penitenciandose heroicamente hora catástrofe tibieza anterior deparar quadro estupendo procurou debalde socorrer únicos soldados ido canudos neste pressuposto ordenou toque repetidos “ meiavolta alto ” notas cornetas convulsivas emitidas corneteiros fôlego vibraram inutilmente melhor – aceleraram fuga naquela desordem havia determinação possível “ debandar ” debalde alguns oficiais indignados engatilhavam revólveres peito foragidos havia contêlos passavam corriam corriam doudamente corriam oficiais corriam jagunços verem preferência alvejados últimos caírem malferidos comoviam capitão vilarim baterase valentemente quase baquear morto encontrou comandava braço sustivesse próprios feridos enfermos estropiados lá iam cambeteando arrastandose penosamente imprecando companheiros ágeisas notas cornetas vibravam cima desse tumulto imperceptíveis inúteispor fim cessaram chamar infantaria desapareceraos sertões 2016em “ tombavam soldados guarnição estoica ” 4° parágrafo termo destacado

reducing food waste would mitigateclimate change study showsapril 7 2016reducing food waste around the world would help curb emission of planetwarming gas lessening some of the impact of climate change such more extreme weather and rising sea scientist said on thursdayup to 14 of emission from agriculture in 2050 could be avoided by managing food use and distribution better according to new study from the potsdam institute climate impact research pik “ agriculture is major driver of climate change accounting more than 20 of overall global greenhouse gas emission in 2010 ” said coauthor prajal pradhan “ avoiding food loss and waste would therefore avoid unnecessary greenhouse gas emission and help mitigate climate change ” between 30 and 40 of food produced around the world is never eaten because it is spoiled after harvest and during transportation or thrown away by shop and consumer the share of food wasted is expected to increase drastically if emerging economy like china and india adopt western food habit including shift to eating more meat the researcher warned richer country tend to consume more food than is healthy or simply waste it they notedas poorer country develop and the world ’ s population grows emission associated with food waste could soar from 05 gigatonnes gt of carbon dioxide equivalent per year to between 19 and 25 gt annually by midcentury showed the study published in the environmental science amp technology journal it is widely argued that cutting food waste and distributing the world ’ s surplus food where it is needed could help tackle hunger in place that not have enough especially given that land to expand farming is limitedbut jürgen kropp another of the study ’ s coauthor and pik ’ s head of climate change and development told the thomson reuters foundation the potential food waste curb to reduce emission should be given more attention “ it is not strategy of government at the moment ” he saidwwwtheguardiancom adaptadono trecho segundo parágrafo “ agriculture is major driver of climate change ” termos destaque têm sentido equivalente português

leia crônica “ premonitório ” carlos drummond andrade 19021987 responder questões 01 09do fundo pernambuco pai mandoulhe telegrama “ saia casa 3 outubro abraços ” rapaz releu sob emoção grave ainda bem velho avisara cima hora avisara olhou data 28 setembro puxa vida telegrama nota urgente levar cinco dia garanhuns belo horizonte revolução telégrafo endireita passado sete manhã veja pai tomara mingau broa precipitarase agência expedir mensagemnão havia tempo perder marcara encontros dia seguinte precisava cancelar tudo alarde deve agir tai ocasiões pegou telefone pediu linha voz d anita respondeu havia tempo morava naquele hotel jamais deixara ouvir “ poi ” melodioso d anita durante dia voz grossa resmungara qualquer coisa empregado casa insistira “ ” ligação dificultosa havia besouros linha falou rapidamente diversas pessoas aludiu ponte talvez resistisse ainda un dia oportunidade escandir sílabas arma virumque cano1 disse achava pouco cem mil unidades tal emergência arrematou “ dia 4 conversamos ” vestiuse desceu portaria sujeito panamá bege chapéu aba larga sapato duas core levantouse seguiuo tomou carro outro fez desceu praça liberdade pôsse contemplar ponto qualquer tirou bolso caderninho anotou qualquer coisa aí havia doi sujeitos panamá aba larga sapato bicolor confabulando pequena distância saindo mansinho doi seguiram cola calmo telegrama pai dobrado carteira placidez satisfeita alma pai avisara tempo tudo correria bem ia tomar calçada baioneta riste advertiu “ passe largo ” delegacia fiscal cercada praças havia armas cruzadas canto correios mesma coisa telefônica bondes passavam escoltados caminhões conduziam tropa jipes chispavam manchetes jornais sombrias pouca gente rua céu escuro abafado chuva próximapensando bem melhor recolherse hotel havia nada fazer trancouse quarto procurou ler vez telefone chamava “ desculpe engano ” ficava mudo desligar dizendose incomodado jantou quarto estranhou camareira olhava móveis bichos deliberou deitarse embora noite apenas começasse releu telegrama apagou luzacordou assustado golpes porta cinco manhã alguém convidava ir delegacia ordem política social “ deve engano ” “ chefe espera ” “ tão cedinho precisa hoje amanhã vou ” “ hoje ” “ impossível ” pegaramlhe braços levaramno polêmica cidade praça guerra toda polícia postos “ senhor vai dizer verdade bonitinho logo ” – disselhe chefe – “ sabe respeito troço ” “ faça bobo troço vai estourar hoje ” “ vai estourar ” “ sabia ponte senhor ia dinamitar difícil ” “ doutor falei dentista trabalho prótese anda abalado quer ver tiro ” “ frase código vagabundo palavras todo mundo manja logo arma cano ” “ professor latim corrigi epígrafe trabalho ” “ latim hem conversa sobre cem mil homens davam vencer ” “ unidades penicilina colega tomou infecção ouvido ” “ cálculos senhor fazia diante palácio ” emudeceu “ diga vamos ” “ desculpe un versinhos aqui bolso ” “ senhor esperto saia desta vê telegrama cópia senhor recebeu pernambuco ainda coragem negar alheio golpe ” “ ah então telegrama custou tanto chegar ” “ custou país gritou chefe sabe causa forças armada ficaram prontidão custa cinco mil conto diga depressa ” “ doutor… ” levado outra sala onde ficou horas aconteceu deus sabe afinal exausto confessou “ senhor entende conversa pai pra filho papai costuma ter sonhos premonitórios toda família acredita neles sonhou aconteceria coisa dia 3 saísse casa telegrafou prevenindo juro ” dia 4 golpe nenhum mandado paz sonho confirmara realmente devia ter saído casa70 historinhas 20161 arma virumque cano “ canto armas varão ” palavras iniciais epopeia eneida escritor vergílio referentes herói eneias “ falou rapidamente diversas pessoas aludiu ponte talvez resistisse ainda un dia oportunidade escandir sílabas arma virumque leia texto responder questões 34 44mobile milestone how your phonebecame an essential part of your lifecomposite prguardianhas any device changed our life much and quickly the mobile phone there are people today whom the world of address book street atlas and phone box seems very far away lost in the mist of time following there are just some of the big milestone from the past 30 year that have made almost everything we easier more public and very very fast• the first phone arrive – and become status symbolsfew people got the chance to use the very early mobile phone the first call wa made in new york in 1973 but handset with network to use were not available until 1983 in the u and 1985 in the uk that first british mobile phone wa essentially heavy briefcase with receiver attached by wire it cost £2000 £5000 in today ’ s price and gave you half an hour ’ s chat on an overnight charge making call wa not something you could subtly but that wasn ’ t the point the first handset were there to be seen they sent message that you were bold and confident with new technology that you were busy and important enough to need mobile phone and were rich enough to buy one• text message spawn whole new languagethe first mobile worked with analogue signal and could only make phone call but the digital one that followed in the early 1990s could send sm message well after the first message wa sent on 3 december 1992 texting took off like rocket even though it wa still pretty cumbersome procedure handset with predictive text would make thing easier but in the 1990s you could save lot of time by removing all excess letter from message often the vowel and so txtspk w brn today the average mobile phone sends more than 100 text per month• phone turn u all into photographersthere seemed to be good reason the first camera phone which began to appear in 2002 with resolution of about 03 megapixels they took grainy blurry picture on postage stampsized screen and even these filled the phone ’ s memory in time gradually though the quality improved the us followed well the usual photo of friend and family they were handy “ saving ” piece of paper and in pub you could take picture of the special board and take it back to your table modern camera phone have changed beyond recognition in the past 20 year the new mobile phone boast the highest resolution dual camera on smartphone 16 megapixel camera and 20megapixel camera sidebyside the dual camera allows user to focus on their subject while blurring out the background producing professionallooking portraits• …and we turn ourselves into celebritiestwenty year ago people would have thought you little strange if you took flattering photo of yourself and your lifestyle and then distributed them to your friend – let alone to member of the public if you used printed photograph rather than smartphone app they would still think so today yet sharing our life on social medium is now the norm not the exception – and it wa the camera phone that made it all possible now some phone come with an enormous 64gb of memory so you can capture share and store an almost countless number of video and picture – well certainly enough to keep up with the kardashianswwwtheguardiancom 07072017 adaptadoaccording to the third paragraph people started to shorten word when writing message by mobile phone because

leia trecho inicial conto “ doida ” carlos drummond andrade responder àquestãoa doida habitava chalé centro jardim maltratado rua descia córrego onde meninos costumavam banharse chalezinho esquerda barranco chão abandonado direita muro grande quintal rua tornada maior silêncio burro pastava rua cheia capim pedras soltas declive áspero onde fiscal mandava capinálaos três garotos desceram manhã cedo banho pega passarinho intenção bom passar casa doida provocála mães diziam contrário horroroso poucos pecados maiores doidos devemos ter piedade porque gozam benefícios sãos aquinhoados explicavam bem quais benefícios explicavam demais restava impressão todos privilégios gente adulta fazer visitas receber cartas entrar irmandades comovia ninguém loucura parecia ante erro miséria três sentiamse inclinados lapidar1 doida isolada agreste jardimcomo cara doida poucos poderiam dizêlo aparecia frente corpo inteiro outras pessoas conversando calma busto recortado janelas frente mãos magras ameaçando cabelos brancos desgrenhados boca inflamada soltando xingamentos pragas voz rouca palavras bíblia misturadas termos populares quais alguns pareciam escabrosos todos fortíssimos cólerasabiase confusamente doida sido moça igual outras tempo remoto contava sessenta ano loucura idade junta lavraram corpo corria variantes história noiva fazendeiro casamento festa estrondosa própria noite núpcias homem repudiara deus sabe razão marido ergueuse terrível empurroua calor bate boca rolou escada abaixo quebrando ossos arrebentandose doi nunca veriam outros contavam pai marido meninos deformavam conto repudiada todos fechou naquele chalé caminho córrego acabou perdendo juízo perdera ante toda relações ninguém ânimo visitála padeiro mal jogava pão caixa madeira entrada infantil ideia equilíbrio compensação afogava remorsoem vão pais censuravam tal procedimento meninos pais daqueles três feito relação mesma doida outras pessoas sensíveis lamentavam fato sugeriam desse jeito internar doida hospício longe parentes interessavam daí – explicavase forasteiro porventura estranhasse situação – toda cidade doidos quase toda família tornam ferozes trancados sótão disto circulam pacificamente ruas querem fazêlo preferem ficar casa doido deus quis ficasse doido respeitemos vontade remédio loucura nunca nenhum doido curou cidade soubesse cidade sabe bastante leia texto responder questões 34 44mobile milestone how your phonebecame an essential part of your lifehas any device changed our life much and quickly the mobile phone there are people today whom the world of address book street atlas and phone box seems very far away lost in the mist of time following there are just some of the big milestone from the past 30 year that have made almost everything we easier more public and very very fast• the first phone arrive – and become status symbolsfew people got the chance to use the very early mobile phone the first call wa made in new york in 1973 but handset with network to use were not available until 1983 in the u and 1985 in the uk that first british mobile phone wa essentially heavy briefcase with receiver attached by wire it cost £2000 £5000 in today ’ s price and gave you half an hour ’ s chat on an overnight charge making call wa not something you could subtly but that wasn ’ t the point the first handset were there to be seen they sent message that you were bold and confident with new technology that you were busy and important enough to need mobile phone and were rich enough to buy one• text message spawn whole new languagethe first mobile worked with analogue signal and could only make phone call but the digital one that followed in the early 1990s could send sm message well after the first message wa sent on 3 december 1992 texting took off like rocket even though it wa still pretty cumbersome procedure handset with predictive text would make thing easier but in the 1990s you could save lot of time by removing all excess letter from message often the vowel and so txtspk w brn today the average mobile phone sends more than 100 text per month• phone turn u all into photographersthere seemed to be good reason the first camera phone which began to appear in 2002 with resolution of about 03 megapixels they took grainy blurry picture on postage stampsized screen and even these filled the phone ’ s memory in time gradually though the quality improved the us followed well the usual photo of friend and family they were handy “ saving ” piece of paper and in pub you could take picture of the special board and take it back to your table modern camera phone have changed beyond recognition in the past 20 year the new mobile phone boast the highest resolution dual camera on smartphone 16 megapixel camera and 20megapixel camera sidebyside the dual camera allows user to focus on their subject while blurring out the background producing professionallooking portraits• …and we turn ourselves into celebritiestwenty year ago people would have thought you little strange if you took flattering photo of yourself and your lifestyle and then distributed them to your friend – let alone to member of the public if you used printed photograph rather than smartphone app they would still think so today yet sharing our life on social medium is now the norm not the exception – and it wa the camera phone that made it all possible now some phone come with an enormous 64gb of memory so you can capture share and store an almost countless number of video and picture – well certainly enough to keep up with the kardashianswwwtheguardiancom 07072017 adaptadono texto exemplos expressão “ big milestone ” 1° parágrafo

leia texto responder questões 31 35words that define the presentat time when the world is changing more quickly than ever before we need new vocabulary to help u grasp what ’ s happeningcatfishing this word would make more sense if it referred to fishing cat but in fact it refers to people who construct false identity online whether out of boredom loneliness or malice they lure other people into continued messaging correspondence thereby building false relationship with them the apparent source of the term “ catfish ” is 2010 documentary called catfish whose verity ironically enough ha been questionedthere are two way of looking at this 1 the internet cyberspace is wonderful because it give people the freedom to augment or totally change their identity and this is marvellous new dawn human expression new step in human evolution 2 nah it ’ s false dawn because the internet is essentially libertarian arena and such an amoral one lot of “ freedom ” but with attendant social obligation it is new jungle where we must watch our back and struggle survival surely backward step in evolution i lean toward the lattercameron laux wwwbbccom 08082018 adaptadono trecho segundo parágrafo “ they lure other people into continued messaging correspondence ” termo sublinhado sentido português
trecho terceiro parágrafo “ to dispel myth nurserecruitment campaign ” termo sublinhado indica

leia texto responder questões 37 44why so few nurse are menask health professional in any country what the biggest problem in their healthcare system is and one of the most common answer is the shortage of nurse in ageing rich country demand nursing care is becoming increasingly insatiable britain ’ s national health service example ha 40000odd nurse vacancy poor country struggle with the emigration of nurse greener pasture one obvious solution seems neglected recruit more men typically just 510 of nurse registered in given country are men why so fewviews of nursing “ woman ’ s job ” have deep root florence nightingale who established the principle of modern nursing in the 1860s insisted that men ’ s “ hard and horny ” hand were “ not fitted to touch bathe and dress wounded limb ” in britain the royal college of nursing the profession ’ s union did not even admit men member until 1960 some nursing school in america started admitting men only in 1982 after supreme court ruling forced them to senior nurse title such “ sister ” ward manager and “ matron ” which in some country is used men well not help matter unsurprisingly some older people not even know that men can be nurse too male nurse often encounter patient who assume they are doctorsanother problem is that belief about what nursing job entail are often outdated – in way that may be particularly offputting men in film nurse are commonly portrayed the helper of heroic male doctor in fact nurse most of their work independently and are the first responder to patient in crisis to dispel myth nurserecruitment campaign display nursing professional job with career progression specialism like anaesthetic cardiology or emergency care and use skill related to technology innovation and leadership however attracting men without playing to gender stereotype can be tricky “ are you man enough to be nurse ” the slogan of an american campaign wa involved in controversynursing is not career many boy aspire to or are encouraged to consider only twofifths of british parent say they would be proud if their son became nurse because of all this men who go into nursing are usually already closely familiar with the job some are following in the career footstep of their mother others decide that the job would suit them after they see male nurse care relative or they themselves get care from male nurse when hospitalised although many gender stereotype about job and caring have crumbled nursing ha so far remained unaffectedwwweconomistcom 22082018 adaptadono trecho quarto parágrafo “ although many gender stereotype about job and caring have crumbled ” termo sublinhado pode substituído alteração sentido

pediatric group advises parent to read to kidsjune 26 2014by amy graffreading go dog go to your 6 month old might seem like wasted time because she ’ s more likely to eat the book than help you turn the page but statement released by the american academy of pediatrics aap this week say reading in the early year is essential reading out loud get parent talking to their baby and the sound of an adult ’ s voice stimulates that tiny yet rapidly growing brain in the statement the academy advises pediatrician to tell parent to read book to their child from birthreading regularly with young child stimulates optimal pattern of brain development and strengthens parentchild relationship at critical time in child development which in turn build language literacy and socialemotional skill that last lifetime research show that child ’ s brain develops fastar between 0 and 3 than at any other time in life making the early year critical time baby to hear rich oral language the more word child hear directed at them by parent and caregiver the more they learnwhile many baby are read goodnight moon and the very hungry caterpillar every night before bed others never get chance to “ pat the bunny ” study reveal that child from lowincome lesseducated family have significantly fewer book than their more affluent peer by age 4 child in poverty hear 30 million fewer word that those in higherincome household these dramatic gap result in significant learning disadvantage that persist into adulthood the aap hope the new guideline will encourage all parent to start reading from day oneresearch show that when pediatrician talk with parent about reading mom and dad are more likely to fill their home with book and read also to help get more parent reading the aap is partnering with organization such scholastic and too small to fail to help get reading material to new family who need book the mostthis is the first time the aap ha made recommendation on child ’ s literary education and it seems the timing might be just right more and more parent are leaning on screen and electronic gadget to occupy their baby “ the reality of today ’ s world is that we ’ re competing with portable digital medium ” dr alanna levine pediatrician in orangeburg ny told the new york time “ so you really want to arm parent with tool and rationale behind it about why it ’ s important to stick to the basic of thing like book ” httpblogseattlepicom adaptadoconforme texto pais devem ler filhos

leia texto responder questões de18a25america ’ s socialmedia addiction is getting worsea survey in january and february 2019 from the pew research centre think tank found that 69 of american adult use facebook of these user more than half visit the site “ several time day ” youtube is even more popular with 73 of adult saying they watch video on the platform those aged 18 to 24 the figure is 90 instagram photosharing app is used by 37 of adult when pew first conducted the survey in 2012 only slim majority of american used facebook fewer than one in ten had an instagram account american are also spending more time than ever on socialmedia site like facebook there is evidence that limiting such service might yield health benefit paper published last year by melissa hunt rachel marx courtney lipson and jordyn young all of the university of pennsylvania found that limiting socialmedia usage to 10 minute day led to reduction in loneliness depression anxiety and fear another paper from 2014 identified link between heavy socialmedia usage and depression largely due to “ social comparison ” phenomenon whereby user compare themselves to others and come away with lower evaluation of themselveswwweconomistcom 08082019 adaptadoaccording to the second paragraph the excessive use of socialmedia raise question about

leia texto tale ab´sáber responder questões 65 67há berlim casa nunca fecha noite termina jamais pode fato começar qualquer momento dia sete manhã ainda dez lá todos tempo estendem noite dia transformam outra coisa naquela imensa boate pretende expandir plano existência tempo infinito sobre vida cidade construída antiga fábrica − antiga usina energia nazista − todo tipo figura noite encontra festa fantástica alucinada deseja terminar jamaisà luz vida tecno¹ avançada ideias tradicionais dia noite revelam frágeis bem insólitas vida cotidiana sob regime produção lev crer alguns mundo dia tornará definitivamente vazio apenas noite excitada veloz vai concentrar si valor vivonaquela boate muitas outras tudo encerra apenas efeito prolongado sistemático droga encerra pausa respirar vezes tendo passado muitos dia jornada diversão suspensão momentânea muitos apenas tempo mínimo reposição forças próxima jornada extenuante fim política imaginária noitee ainda outros tantos próprio efeito droga sob pulsação infinita música eletrônica experiência programática enfeitiçada deveria encerrar jamais estariam destinados projeto dissolução pulsação música tecno dissolução espírito infantilização fim embates materiais vida dissolução corpo ambo igualmente reaisde fato após noite vida tecno forte experiência radical vazio torna espírito dia energia imensamente gasta noite devastada tornando dia vazio objeto porém vivo vivo vazio bem articulado busca excedente absoluto tarde noitea música tempo infinito 2012 adaptado¹tecno estilo música eletrônica1tecno estilo música eletrônica “ alguns mundo dia tornará definitivamente vazio apenas noite excitada veloz vai concentrar si valor vivo ” 2° parágrafo considerado contexto trecho sugere

leia texto responder questões de11a20can plant hearflora may be able to detect thesounds of flowing water or munching insectspseudoscientific claim that music help plant grow have been made decade despite evidence that is shaky at best yet new research suggests some flora may be capable of sensing sound such the gurgle of water through pipe or the buzzing of insectsin recent study monica gagliano an evolutionary biologist at the university of western australia and her colleague placed pea seedling in pot shaped like an upsidedown y one arm of each pot wa placed in either tray of water or coiled plastic tube through which water flowed the other arm had dry soil the root grew toward the arm of the pipe with the fluid regardless of whether it wa easily accessible or hidden inside the tubing “ they just knew the water wa there even if the only thing to detect wa the sound of it flowing inside the pipe ” gagliano say yet when the seedling were given choice between the water tube and some moistened soil their root favored the latter she hypothesizes that these plant use sound wave to detect water at distance but follow moisture gradient to home in on their target when it is closerthe research reported earlier this year in oecologia is not the first to suggest flora can detect and interpret sound 2014 study showed the rock cress arabidopsis can distinguish between caterpillar chewing sound and wind vibration – the plant produced more chemical toxin after “ hearing ” recording of feeding insect “ we tend to underestimate plant because their response are usually le visible to u but leaf turn out to be extremely sensitive vibration detector ” say lead study author heidi m appel an environmental scientist now at the university of toledomarta zaraska wwwscientificamericancom 17052017what is the topic mainly about

what time is it that simple question probably is asked more often today than ever in our clockstudded cellphone society the answer is never more than glance away and so we can blissfully partition our day into ever smaller increment ever more tightly scheduled task confident that we will always know it is 703 pmmodern scientific revelation about time however make the question endlessly frustrating if we seek precise knowledge of the time the elusive infinitesimal of “ now ” dissolve into scattering flock of nanosecond bound by the speed of light and the velocity of nerve impulse our perception of the present sketch the world it wa an instant ago—for all that our consciousness pretend otherwise we can never catch upeven in principle perfect synchronicity escape u relativity dictate that like strange syrup time flow slower on moving train than in the station and faster in the mountain than in the valley the time our wristwatch or digital screen is not exactly the same the time our headour intuition are deeply paradoxical time heals all wound but it is also the great destroyer time is relative but also relentless there is time every purpose under heaven but there is never enoughscientific american october 24 2014 adaptadono texto expressão melhor representa caráter supostamente exato tempo

texto questões de25a27assigning female gender to digital assistant such apple ’ s siri and amazon ’ s alexa is helping entrench harmful gender bias according to un agencyresearch released by unesco claim that the often submissive and flirty response offered by the systemsto many query – including outright abusive one – reinforce idea of woman subservient “ because the speech of most voice assistant is female it sends signal that woman are obliging docile and eager‐to‐please helper available at the touch of button or with blunt voice command like ‘ hey ’ or ‘ ok ’ ” the report said “ the assistant hold power of agency beyond what the commander asks of it it honour command and responds to query regardless of their tone or hostility in many community this reinforces commonly held gender bias that woman are subservient and tolerant of poor treatment ” the unesco publication wa entitled “ i ’ d blush if i could ” reference to the response apple ’ s siri assistant offer to the phrase “ you ’ re slut ” amazon ’ s alexa will respond “ well thanks the feedback ” the papersaid such firm were “ staffed by overwhelmingly male engineering team ” and have built ai artificial intelligence system that “ cause their feminised digital assistant to greet verbal abuse with catch‐me‐if‐you‐can flirtation ” saniye gülser corat unesco ’ s director gender equality said “ the world need to pay much closer attention to how when and whether ai technology are gendered and crucially who is gendering them ” the guardian may 2019 adaptadosegundo texto título relatório publicado unesco “ i´d blush if i could ” diz respeito assistentes digitais indica

scientist have long touted dna ’ s potential an ideal storage medium it ’ s dense easy to replicate and stable over millennium but in order to replace existing siliconchip or magnetictape storage technology dna will have to get lot cheaper to predictably read write and packagethat ’ s where scientist like hyunjun park come in he and the other cofounder of catalog an mit dnastorage spinoff emerging out of stealth on tuesday are building machine that will write terabyte of data day using 500 trillion molecule of dnaif successful dna storage could be the answer to uniquely 21stcentury problem information overload five year ago human had produced 44 zettabyte of data thats set to explode to 160 zettabyte each year by 2025 current infrastructure can handle only fraction of the coming data deluge which is expected to consume all the world microchipgrade silicon by 2040 “ today ’ s technology is already close to the physical limit of scaling ” say victor zhirnov chief scientist of the semiconductor research corporation “ dna ha an informationstorage density several order of magnitude higher than any other known storage technology ” how dense exactly imagine formatting every movie ever made into dna it would be smaller than the size of sugar cube and it would last 10000 yearswired june 2018 disponível httpswwwwiredcom adaptadoconforme texto cientistas preveem pouco 20 ano

leia texto responder questões 24 27genetically modified foodsgenetically modified gm food are food derived from organism whose genetic material dna ha been modified in way that doe not occur naturally eg through the introduction of gene from different organism currently available gm food stem mostly from plant but in the future food derived from gm microorganism or gm animal are likely to be introduced on the market most existing genetically modified crop have been developed to improve yield through the introduction of resistance to plant disease or of increased tolerance of herbicidesin the future genetic modification could be aimed at altering the nutrient content of food reducing it allergenic potential or improving the efficiency of food production system all gm food should be assessed before being allowed on the market faowho codex guideline exist risk analysis of gm foodwwwwhointde acordo texto vantagens produtos agrícolas geneticamente modificados existentes produtos

texto questões 22 23a study carried out by lauren sherman of the university of california and her colleague investigated how use of the “ like ” button in social medium affect the brain of teenager lying in body scannersthirtytwo teen who had instagram account were asked to lie down in functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri scanner this let dr sherman monitor their brain activity while they were perusing both their own instagram photo and photo that they were told had been added by other teenager in the experiment in reality dr sherman had collected all the other photo which included neutral image of food and friend well many depicting risky behaviour like drinking smoking and drug use from other people ’ instagram account the researcher told participant they were viewing photograph that 50 other teenager had already seen and endorsed with “ like ” in the laboratorythe participant were more likely themselves to “ like ” photo already depicted having been “ liked ” lot than they were photo depicted with fewer previous “ like ” when she looked at the fmri result dr sherman found that activity in the nucleus accumbens hub of reward circuitry in the brain increased with the number of “ like ” that photo hadthe economist june 13 2016 adaptadoconforme texto região cérebro mostrou ativa análise resultados ressonância corresponde sistema

survey of geopoliticsgeopolitics is product of it time and it definition have evolved accordingly rudolphh kjellén who coined the term in 1899 described geopolitics “ the theory of the state geographical organism or phenomenon in space ” karl haushofer the father of german geopolotik “ geopolitics is the new national science of the state … doctrine on the spatial determinism of all political process based on the broad foundation of geography especially of political geography ” on the eve of world war ii derwent whittlesey the american political geographer considered geopolitics “ dogma the faith that the state is inherently entitled to it place in the sun ” richard hartshorne defined it “ geography utilized particular purpose that lie beyond the pursuit of scientific knowledge ” adaptado saul bernard cohen geopolitics of the world system boston rowman amp littlefield publisher 2003 p11conforme texto

responda questões 55 56 acordo texto jonathan wolfe figura ilustranew york todaygoodbye subway seatsby jonathan wolfe oct 5 2017httpswwwnytimescomacessado 10102017 adaptadothe new seatless area on redesignede train car credit metropolitan transit authoritygood morning on this warming thursdaysubway rider have you noticed anything missing from your commute like maybe seat on tuesday the metropolitan transportation authority rolled out redesigned subway car on the line with some of the seat removedthe agency hope that up to 10 more people will be able to squeeze into each new car — meaning 80 to 100 extra commuter per train — to help reduce overcrowding in all 100 car will lose their seat in the pilot program the l train and the 42nd street shuttle are next in line the redesign according to the authorityyesterday we waited at the 34th street station few train to pas before one of the refurbished model with it navy blue wrapping pulled into the stationwith the seat removed at the front and back of the car it felt roomy even dare we say luxurious — though that likely won ’ t be the case during rush hour people were enthusiastic about the interior calling them “ bright ” “ cheerful ” even “ beautiful ” the deleted seat review were mixedassinale alternativa correta

3689about half of the world ’ s population is at risk of contracting dengue according to the world health organization the mosquito is found in tropical and subtropical climate around the world however dengue doe not naturally occur in these creature the mosquito get dengue from usthe mechanism of dengue infection is simple female mosquito bite human because they need the protein found in our blood to produce egg male mosquito not bite if the mosquito bite someone with dengue – and then after the virus ’ s roughly eight to 12day replication period bite someone else – it pass dengue into it next victim ’ s bloodstreamthere is vaccine against dengue but infecting mosquito with natural bacterium called wolbachia block the insect ’ ability to pas the disease to human the microbe spread among both male and female mosquito infected female lay egg that harbor the bacterium and when wolbachiafree female mate with infected male their egg simple not hatch researcher are now releasing wolbachiainfected female into the wild in australia vietnam indonesia and brazilscientific american june 2015 adaptadosegundo texto bactéria wolbachia inoculada mosquito bloqueia transmissão dengue porqueferramenta imagem

working ondemand startup like uber and taskrabbit is supposed to offer flexible hour and higher wage but many worker have found the pay lower and the hour le flexible than they expected even more surprising 8 percent of those chauffeuring passenger and 16 percent of those making delivery said they lack personal auto insurancethose are among the finding from survey about the work life of independent contractor ondemand startup booming sector of the tech industry being released wednesday “ we want to shed light on the industry whole ” said isaac madan stanford master ’ s candidate in bioinformatics who worked with two other stanford student and recent alumnus on the survey of 1330 worker “ people need to understand how this space will change and evolve and help the economy ” ondemand often called the sharing economy refers to company that let user summon worker via smartphone apps to handle all manner of service ride cleaning chore delivery car parking waiting in line almost uniformly those worker are independent contractor rather than salaried employeesthat status is the main point of contention in recent rash of lawsuit in which worker are filing employee status while the survey did not directly ask contractor if they would prefer to be employee it found that their top workplace desire were to have paid health insurance retirement benefit and paid time off holiday vacation and sick day – all perk of fulltime worker respondent also expressed interest in having more chance advancement education sponsorship disability insurance and humanrelations supportbecause respondent were recruited rather than randomly selected the survey doe not claim to be representational but conclusion one may come to is that flexibility of new job come with cost not all worker are prepared thatsfchroniclecom and sfgatecom may 20 2015 adaptadooutro resultado mesma pesquisa indica

the modern fma form of newton ’ s second law occurs nowhere in any edition of the principia even though he had seen his second law formulated in this way in print during the interval between the second and third edition in jacob hermann ’ phoronomia of 1716 instead it ha the following formulation in all three edition change in 1 is proportional to the motive 2 impressed and take place along the 3 line in which that force is 4 in the body of the principia this law is applied both to 5 case in which an instantaneous impulse such from impact is effecting the change in motion and to case of 6 action such the change in motion in the continuous deceleration of body moving in resisting medium newton thus appears to have intended his second law to be neutral between discrete force that is what we now call impulse and continuous forcesadaptado george smith “ newton ’ s philosophiae naturalisprincipia mathematica ” edward n zalta ed the stanford encyclopedia of philosophy winter 2008 edition disponível httpsplatostanfordeduarchiveswin2008entriesnewtonprincipia acessado 24102017assinale alternativa apresenta sequência adequada palavras preenchem lacuna texto acima conceitos utilizados corretos
