responder questões 09 15 leia texto extraído primeira parte intitulada “ terra ” obra sertões euclides cunha obra resultou cobertura jornalística guerra canudos realizada euclides cunha jornal estado spaulo agosto outubro 1897 publicada apenas 1902percorrendo certa vez fin setembro 1897 cercanias canudos fugindo monotonia canhoneio1 frouxo tiro espaçados soturnos encontramos descer encosta anfiteatro irregular onde colinas dispunham circulando vale único pequenos arbustos icozeiros2 virentes viçando tufos intermeados palmatórias3 flores rutilantes davam lugar aparência exata algum velho jardim abandono lado árvore única quixabeira alta sobranceando vegetação franzinao sol poente desatava longa sombra chão protegido — braços largamente abertos face volvida céus — soldado descansavadescansava havia três mesesmorrera assalto 18 julho 1897 coronha mannlicher4 estrondada cinturão boné jogados banda farda tiras diziam sucumbira luta corpo corpo adversário possante caíra certo derreandose violenta pancada sulcara fronte manchada escara preta enterrarem dia mortos percebido compartira vala comum menos côvado fundo jogados formando última vez junto companheiros abatidos batalha destino removera lar desprotegido fizeralhe afinal concessão livrarao promiscuidade lúgubre fosso repugnante deixarao ali três me – braços largamente abertos rosto voltado céus sóis ardentes luares claro estrelas fulgurantes intacto murchara apenas mumificara conservando traços fisionômicos modo incutir ilusão exata lutador cansado retemperandose tranquilo sono sombra daquela árvore benfazeja verme — vulgar trágicos analistas matéria — maculara tecidos volvia turbilhão vida decomposição repugnante exaustão imperceptível aparelho revelando modo absoluto sugestivo secura extremum leia narrativa “ leão burro rato ” millôr fernandes responder questões 16 19um leão burro rato voltaram afinal caçada haviam empreendido juntos1 colocaram clareira tudo caçado doi veados algumas perdizes três tatu paca muita caça menor leão sentouse tronco voz tonitruante procurava inutilmente suavizar berrou— bem agora terminamos magnífico dia trabalho descansemos aqui camaradas justa partilha esforço conjunto compadre burro favor sábio três licença compadre rato compadre burro vai fazer partilha desta caça três partes absolutamente iguais vamos compadre rato rio beber pouco água deixando grande amigo burro paz deliberaros doi afastaram rio beberam água2 ficaram tempo voltaram verificaram burro feito trabalho extremamente meticuloso dividindo caça três partes absolutamente iguais assim viu doi voltando burro perguntou leão— pronto compadre leão aí acha partilhao leão disse palavra deu violenta patada nuca burro prostrandoo chão mortosorrindo leão voltouse rato disse— compadre rato lamento impressão concorda podíamos suportar presença tamanha inaptidão burrice desculpe ter perdido paciência havia outra coisa fazer suportava compadre burro faça favor agora — divida bolo caça incluindo favor corpo compadre burro vou rio novamente deixandolhe calma deliberação sensatamal leão afastou rato menor dúvida dividiu monte caça doi lado toda caça inclusive corpo burro outro apenas ratinho cinza morto acaso leão ainda chegado rio rato chamou— compadre leão pronta partilhao leão vendo caça dividida maneira tão justa pôde deixar cumprimentar rato— maravilhoso caro compadre maravilhoso chegou tão depressa partilha tão certae rato respondeu— simple estabeleci relação matemática tamanho — claro precisa comer tracei comparação força — claro precisa maior volume alimentação comparei ponderadamente posição floresta — evidentemente partilha podium além intelectual todo espírito— inacreditável inacreditável compreensão argúcia — exclamou leão realmente admirado — olha juro nunca notado cultura escondeu tempo todo ensinou tanta sabedoria— verdade leão nunca soube nada perdoa elogio fúnebre ofende acabei aprender tudo agora burro mortomoral burro tenta ficar parte leão1 conjugação esforços tão heterogêneos destruição meio ambiente coisa comum2 enquanto bebendo água leão reparou rato sujando água bebia outra fábula100 fábulas fabulosas 2012a narrativa millôr fernandes afastase modelo tradicional fábula medida emprega tom

responder questões 02 06 leia trecho contoprefácio “ hipotrélico ” integra livro tutameia joão guimarães rosahá hipotrélico termo novo impesquisada origem ainda definição apanhe toda pétalas significado sabese vem bom português prática tomese hipotrélico querendo dizer antipodático sengraçante imprizido talvez vicedito indivíduo pedante importuno agudo falto respeito opinião alheia sob tratandose palavra inventada adiante verá embirrando hipotrélico tolerar neologismos começa negar nominalmente própria existênciasomos todos neste ponto tento cento hipotrélicos salvo excepto neologismo contunde confunde quase ofende perspicanos inércia soneja cada canto espírito refestela bons hábitos estadados assuste saia todo omundo empinar vocábulos aonde vai dar língua tida herdada assentanos bem modéstia achar novo valerá velho ajustase melhor prudência relegar progresso passado outro contudo respeitável caso — enfim — “ hipotrélico ” motivo base desta fábula diversa vem bom português bom português homemde bem muitíssimo inteligente neologizava segundo necessidades íntimasora poi roda dizia algum sicrano terceiro ausente— hiputrélicoao indesejável maçante contendo emitiu veto— olhe amigo palavra existeparou bom português olhálo tanto perplexo— os poi dizer— existeaí bom português ainda meio enfigadado tom feliz descoberta apontando outro peremptório— senhor hiputrélicoe ficou havendotutameia 1979retoma termo mencionado anteriormente texto palavra sublinhada

texto questões 89 90algorithms are everywhere they play the stockmarket decide whether you can have mortgage and may one day drive your car you they search the internet when commanded stick carefully chosen advertisement into the site you visit and decide what price to show you in online shop … but what exactly are algorithm and what make them so powerfulan algorithm is essentially brainless way of doing clever thing it is set of precise step that need great mental effort to follow but which if obeyed exactly and mechanically will lead to some desirable outcome long division and column addition are example that everyone is familiar with—if you follow the procedure you are guaranteed to get the right answer so is the strategy rediscovered thousand of time every year by schoolchildren bored with learning mathematical algorithm playing perfect game of nought and cross the brainlessness is key each step should be simple and free from ambiguity possible cooking recipe and driving direction are algorithm of sort but instruction like “ stew the meat until tender ” or “ it ’ s few mile down the road ” are too vague to follow without at least some interpretation…the economist august 30 2017segundo texto execução algoritmo consiste processo

texto questões 25 27assigning female gender to digital assistant such apple ’ s siri and amazon ’ s alexa is helping entrench harmful gender bias according to un agencyresearch released by unesco claim that the often submissive and flirty response offered by the system to many query – including outright abusive one – reinforce idea of woman subservient “ because the speech of most voice assistant is female it sends signal that woman are obliging docile and eagertoplease helper available at the touch of button or with blunt voice command like ‘ hey ’ or ‘ ok ’ ” the report said “ the assistant hold power of agency beyond what the commander asks of it it honour command and responds to query regardless of their tone or hostility in many community this reinforces commonly held gender bias that woman are subservient and tolerant of poor treatment ” the unesco publication wa entitled “ i ’ d blush if i could ” reference to the response apple ’ s siri assistant offer to the phrase “ you ’ re slut ” amazon ’ s alexa will respond “ well thanks the feedback ” the paper said such firm were “ staffed by overwhelmingly male engineering team ” and have built ai artificial intelligence system that “ cause their feminised digital assistant to greet verbal abuse with catchmeifyoucan flirtation ” saniye gülser corat unesco ’ s director gender equality said “ the world need to pay much closer attention to how when and whether ai technology are gendered and crucially who is gendering them ” the guardian may 2019 adaptadode acordo texto opinião saniye gülser corat tecnologias envolvem inteligência artificial outros aspectos

working ondemand startup like uber and taskrabbit is supposed to offer flexible hour and higher wage but many worker have found the pay lower and the hour le flexible than they expected even more surprising 8 percent of those chauffeuring passenger and 16 percent of those making delivery said they lack personal auto insurancethose are among the finding from survey about the work life of independent contractor ondemand startup booming sector of the tech industry being released wednesday “ we want to shed light on the industry whole ” said isaac madan stanford master ’ s candidate in bioinformatics who worked with two other stanford student and recent alumnus on the survey of 1330 worker “ people need to understand how this space will change and evolve and help the economy ” ondemand often called the sharing economy refers to company that let user summon worker via smartphone apps to handle all manner of service ride cleaning chore delivery car parking waiting in line almost uniformly those worker are independent contractor rather than salaried employeesthat status is the main point of contention in recent rash of lawsuit in which worker are filing employee status while the survey did not directly ask contractor if they would prefer to be employee it found that their top workplace desire were to have paid health insurance retirement benefit and paid time off holiday vacation and sick day – all perk of fulltime worker respondent also expressed interest in having more chance advancement education sponsorship disability insurance and humanrelations supportbecause respondent were recruited rather than randomly selected the survey doe not claim to be representational but conclusion one may come to is that flexibility of new job come with cost not all worker are prepared thatsfchroniclecom and sfgatecom may 20 2015 adaptadoum resultados pesquisa realizada prestadores serviços empresas tipo “ ondemand ” mostra trabalhadores

leia texto responder questões 24 27genetically modified foodsgenetically modified gm food are food derived from organism whose genetic material dna ha been modified in way that doe not occur naturally eg through the introduction of gene from different organism currently available gm food stem mostly from plant but in the future food derived from gm microorganism or gm animal are likely to be introduced on the market most existing genetically modified crop have been developed to improve yield through the introduction of resistance to plant disease or of increased tolerance of herbicidesin the future genetic modification could be aimed at altering the nutrient content of food reducing it allergenic potential or improving the efficiency of food production system all gm food should be assessed before being allowed on the market faowho codex guideline exist risk analysis of gm foodwwwwhointno trecho segundo parágrafo “ all gm food should be assessed before being allowed on the market ” termo destaque pode corretamente substituído alteração sentido

texto questões 22 23a study carried out by lauren sherman of the university of california and her colleague investigated how use of the “ like ” button in social medium affect the brain of teenager lying in body scannersthirtytwo teen who had instagram account were asked to lie down in functional magnetic resonance imaging fmri scanner this let dr sherman monitor their brain activity while they were perusing both their own instagram photo and photo that they were told had been added by other teenager in the experiment in reality dr sherman had collected all the other photo which included neutral image of food and friend well many depicting risky behaviour like drinking smoking and drug use from other people ’ instagram account the researcher told participant they were viewing photograph that 50 other teenager had already seen and endorsed with “ like ” in the laboratorythe participant were more likely themselves to “ like ” photo already depicted having been “ liked ” lot than they were photo depicted with fewer previous “ like ” when she looked at the fmri result dr sherman found that activity in the nucleus accumbens hub of reward circuitry in the brain increased with the number of “ like ” that photo hadthe economist june 13 2016 adaptadosegundo texto resultado parcial pesquisa observouse

assigning female gender to digital assistant such apple ’ s siri and amazon ’ s alexa is helping entrench harmful gender bias according to un agencyresearch released by unesco claim that the often submissive and flirty response offered by the system to many query – including outright abusive one – reinforce idea of woman subservient “ because the speech of most voice assistant is female it sends signal that woman are obliging docile and eagertoplease helper available at the touch of button or with blunt voice command like ‘ hey ’ or ‘ ok ’ ” the report said “ the assistant hold power of agency beyond what the commander asks of it it honour command and responds to query regardless of their tone or hostility in many community this reinforces commonly held gender bias that woman are subservient and tolerant of poor treatment ” the unesco publication wa entitled “ i ’ d blush if i could ” reference to the response apple ’ s siri assistant offer to the phrase “ you ’ re slut ” amazon ’ s alexa will respond “ well thanks the feedback ” the paper said such firm were “ staffed by overwhelmingly male engineering team ” and have built ai artificial intelligence system that “ cause their feminised digital assistant to greet verbal abuse with catchmeifyoucan flirtation ” saniye gülser corat unesco ’ s director gender equality said “ the world need to pay much closer attention to how when and whether ai technology are gendered and crucially who is gendering them ” the guardian may 2019 adaptadoconforme texto relação mulheres efeito decorrente fato assistentes digitais reforçarem estereótipos gênero

texto questões 89 90algorithms are everywhere they play the stockmarket decide whether you can have mortgage and may one day drive your car you they search the internet when commanded stick carefully chosen advertisement into the site you visit and decide what price to show you in online shop … but what exactly are algorithm and what make them so powerfulan algorithm is essentially brainless way of doing clever thing it is set of precise step that need great mental effort to follow but which if obeyed exactly and mechanically will lead to some desirable outcome long division and column addition are example that everyone is familiar with—if you follow the procedure you are guaranteed to get the right answer so is the strategy time every year by rediscovered thousand of schoolchildren bored with learning mathematical algorithm playing perfect game of nought and cross the brainlessness is key each step should be simple and free from ambiguity possible cooking recipe and driving direction are algorithm of sort but instruction like “ stew the meat until tender ” or “ it ’ s few mile down the road ” are too vague to follow without at least some interpretation …the economist august 30 2017no texto exemplo associado fato algoritmos estarem toda parte

texto questões 19 21plants not only remember when you touch them but they can also make risky decision that are sophisticated those made by human all without brain or complex nervous systemsresearchers showed that when faced with the choice between pot containing constant level of nutrient or one with unpredictable level plant will pick the mystery pot when condition are sufficiently poorin set of experiment dr shemesh from telhai college in israel and alex kacelnik from oxford university grew pea plant and split their root between two pot both pot had the same amount of nutrient on average but in one the level were constant in the other they varied over time then the researcher switched the condition so that the average nutrient in both pot would be equally high or low and asked which pot would plant preferwhen nutrient level were low the plant laid more root in the unpredictable pot but when nutrient were abundant they chose the one that always had the same amountthe new york time june 30 2016 adaptadoconforme texto elementos metodologia empregada experimentos

genetic fortunetellingone day baby will get dna report card at birth these report will offer prediction abouttheir chance of suffering heart attack or cancer of getting hooked on tobacco and of being smarter than averagethough the new dna test offer probability not diagnosis they could greatly benefit medicine example if woman at high risk breast cancer got more mammogram and those at low risk got fewer those exam might catch more real cancer and set off fewer false alarm the trouble is the prediction are far from perfect what if someone with low risk score cancer put off being screened and then develops cancer anyway polygenic score are also controversial because they can predict any trait not only disease instance they can now forecast about 10 percent of person ’ s performance on iq test but how will parent and educator use that informationadaptado derek brahney genetic fortunetelling mittechnology review marçoabril 2018de acordo texto riscos prognóstico genético indivíduos desde nascimento deferramenta imagem

leia texto responder questões 11 19plenty of opportunity exist to study and work abroad but some earlycareer scientist might face challenge adjusting to different communication style and different workplace and academic hierarchiesit is important both to be sensitive to cultural difference and to avoid inadvertently stereotyping also assumption should not be made about student solely on the basis of their culture wealthy chinese student from hong kong example could see thing differently from one who come from rural area on the mainland and individual perception can vary too one student may personally encounter directness more often in the united kingdom than in the united state but others might not have experienced this the relationship between researcher and supervisor is influenced by many factor including personality previous experience and the workplace cultureone point of difference that can arise is the appropriate level of deference to supervisor some nigerian egyptian and chinese international student report that in their home nation large power differential between student and teacher is common and that student generally follow instruction without arguing but supervisor from country where debate is expected might sometimes incorrectly interpret lack of questioning from the student lack of interest in the work the absence of strictly defined hierarchy can encourage freer communication say salim reza radiationdetector scientist when he moved from his native bangladesh to sweden graduate study he learnt that he did not need to address faculty member ‘ sir ’ or ‘ professor ’ or remain standing in their office this informality made it easier him to approach professor to clarify topic or to propose new research anglesometimes though misunderstanding can stem from difference in communication style in some country the ‘ feedback sandwich ’ is common start with praise suggest improvement and end with encouragement student from country where this format is le common might think that because comment were mostly positive the suggestion are optional and can be ignored conversely student who is accustomed to gentler feedback might be ‘ traumatized ’ by cultural tendency in other country such germany or the netherlands to give more direct criticism senior researcher could smooth over difference by freely discussing how the student prefers to receive comment student could also talk to lab mate about the feedback hearing others ’ story could help them overcome discouragementwhether they are welcoming international student or starting work in new country scientist can ease the transition by remaining nonjudgemental people sometimes brush off student from another country ‘ rude ’ but “ in their culture they ’ re not ” researcher should also remember that their nation ’ s custom aren ’ t necessarily best “ when you come from small country you don ’ t assume everybody should be doing thing your way ” say croatian student “ i never cared if somebody wa different than long it didn ’ t seriously affect the rest of the lab ” roberta kwok wwwnaturecom 23052018 adaptadoo terceiro parágrafo discute principalmente questões relativas

responda questões 55 63 acordo texto abaixothe drug don ’ t work what happens after antibioticsantibiotic resistance is growing so fast that routine surgery could soon become impossible but scientist are fighting back in the battle against infection9426 ‘ you essentially trick the bacteria ’ kim lewis one of two researcher who discovered teixobactin photograph adam glanzman1 the first antibiotic that didn ’ t work debbi forsythe wa trimethoprim in march 2016 forsythe genial primary care counsellor from morpeth northumberland contracted urinary tract infection utis are common more than 150 million people worldwide contract one every year so when forsythe saw her gp they prescribed the usual treatment threeday course of antibiotic when few week later she fainted and started passing blood she saw her gp again who again prescribed trimethoprim2 three day after that forsythe ’ s husband pete came home to find his wife lying on the sofa shaking unable to call help he rushed her to aampe she wa put on second antibiotic gentamicin and treated sepsis complication of the infection that can be fatal if not treated quickly the gentamicin didn ’ t work either doctor sent forsythe ’ s blood testing but such test can take day bacteria must be grown in culture then tested against multiple antibiotic to find suitable treatment five day after she wa admitted to hospital forsythe wa diagnosed with an infection of multidrug resistant coli and given ertapenem one of the socalled “ last resort ” antibiotics3 it worked but damage from forsythe ’ s episode ha lingered and she life in constant fear of an infection reoccurring six month after her collapse she developed another uti resulting again in hospital stay “ i ’ ve had to accept that i will longer get back to where i wa ” infection she say “ my daughter and son said they felt like they lost their mum because i wasn ’ t who i used to be ” but forsythe wa fortunate sepsis currently kill more people in the uk than lung cancer and the number is growing more of u develop infection immune to antibiotics4 antimicrobial resistance amr – the process of bacteria and yeast and virus evolving defense mechanism against the drug we use to treat them – is progressing so quickly that the un ha called it “ global health emergency ” at least 2 million american contract drugresistant every year socalled “ superbug ” spread rapidly in part because some bacteria are able to borrow resistance gene from neighbouring specie via process called horizontal gene transfer in 2013 researcher in china discovered coli containing mcr1 gene resistant to colistin lastline antibiotic that until recently wa considered too toxic human use colistinresistant infection have now been detected in at least 30 countries5 “ in india and pakistan bangladesh china and country in south america the resistance problem is already endemic ” say colin garner ceo of antibiotic research uk in may 2016 the uk government ’ s review on antimicrobial resistance forecast that by 2050 antibioticresistant infection could kill 10 million people per year – more than all cancer combined6 “ we have good chance of getting to point where lot of people there are effective antibiotic ” daniel berman leader of the global health team at nesta told the threat is difficult to imagine world without antibiotic mean returning to time without organ transplant without hip replacement without many nowroutine surgery it would mean million more woman dying in childbirth make many cancer treatment including chemotherapy impossible and make even the smallest wound potentially lifethreatening berman told “ those of u who are following this closely are actually quite scared ” 7 bacteria are everywhere in our body in the air in the soil coating every surface in their sextillion many bacteria produce antibiotic compound – exactly how many we don ’ t know – probably weapon in microscopic battle resource between different strain of bacteria that ha been going on billion of year because bacteria reproduce so quickly they are able to evolve with astonishing speed introduce bacteria to sufficiently weak concentration of an antibiotic and resistance can emerge within day penicillin resistance wa first documented in 1940 year before it first use in human common misconception is that people can become antibioticresistant they don ’ t – the bacteria dooliver franklinwallissun 24 mar 2019in httpswwwtheguardiancomglobal2019mar24thedrugsdontworkwhathappensafterantibioticsno sexto parágrafo outra maneira dizer “ those of u who are following this closely are actually quite scared ” pode

leia texto bernadette siqueira abrão responder questões 09 10rousseau explica contrato saída estado natureza apelando hipótese homens chegado ponto obstáculos conservação sobrepujaram forças cada indivíduo dispõe manterse têm outra saída portanto unir juntar forças força liberdade cada indivíduo instrumentos primordiais conservação estado natureza solução prevista lev impasse empenhálas prejudicar negligenciar cuidados si cada deve resolver questão efetuar pacto homem precisa encontrar “ forma associação defenda proteja pessoa ben cada associado toda força comum cada unindose todos obedece contudo si permanecendo assim tão livre quanto ante ” pacto exige alienação1 total cada associado todos direitos comunidade “ cada dandose todos dá ninguém ” recebe equivalente tudo alienou maior força conservar todos ganham ninguém perde homem deixa estado natureza ingressar sociedade civil necessárias regras sobrevivênciahistória filosofia 19991alienação renúncia abandonosegundo texto caso aplicada hipótese rousseau resultaria sociedade

leia texto responder questões 11 19plenty of opportunity exist to study and work abroad but some earlycareer scientist might face challenge adjusting to different communication style and different workplace and academic hierarchiesit is important both to be sensitive to cultural difference and to avoid inadvertently stereotyping also assumption should not be made about student solely on the basis of their culture wealthy chinese student from hong kong example could see thing differently from one who come from rural area on the mainland and individual perception can vary too one student may personally encounter directness more often in the united kingdom than in the united state but others might not have experienced this the relationship between researcher and supervisor is influenced by many factor including personality previous experience and the workplace cultureone point of difference that can arise is the appropriate level of deference to supervisor some nigerian egyptian and chinese international student report that in their home nation large power differential between student and teacher is common and that student generally follow instruction without arguing but supervisor from country where debate is expected might sometimes incorrectly interpret lack of questioning from the student lack of interest in the work the absence of strictly defined hierarchy can encourage freer communication say salim reza radiationdetector scientist when he moved from his native bangladesh to sweden graduate study he learnt that he did not need to address faculty member ‘ sir ’ or ‘ professor ’ or remain standing in their office this informality made it easier him to approach professor to clarify topic or to propose new research anglesometimes though misunderstanding can stem from difference in communication style in some country the ‘ feedback sandwich ’ is common start with praise suggest improvement and end with encouragement student from country where this format is le common might think that because comment were mostly positive the suggestion are optional and can be ignored conversely student who is accustomed to gentler feedback might be ‘ traumatized ’ by cultural tendency in other country such germany or the netherlands to give more direct criticism senior researcher could smooth over difference by freely discussing how the student prefers to receive comment student could also talk to lab mate about the feedback hearing others ’ story could help them overcome discouragementwhether they are welcoming international student or starting work in new country scientist can ease the transition by remaining nonjudgemental people sometimes brush off student from another country ‘ rude ’ but “ in their culture they ’ re not ” researcher should also remember that their nation ’ s custom aren ’ t necessarily best “ when you come from small country you don ’ t assume everybody should be doing thing your way ” say croatian student “ i never cared if somebody wa different than long it didn ’ t seriously affect the rest of the lab ” roberta kwok wwwnaturecom 23052018 adaptado “ the feedback sandwich ” mentioned in the fourth paragraphferramenta imagem

the drug don ’ t work what happens after antibioticsantibiotic resistance is growing so fast that routine surgery could soon become impossible but scientist are fighting back in the battle against infection ‘ you essentially trick the bacteria ’ kim lewis one of two researcher who discovered teixobactin photograph adam glanzman1 the first antibiotic that didn ’ t work debbi forsythe wa trimethoprim in march 2016 forsythe genial primary care counsellor from morpeth northumberland contracted urinary tract infection utis are common more than 150 million people worldwide contract one every year so when forsythe saw her gp they prescribed the usual treatment threeday course of antibiotic when few week later she fainted and started passing blood she saw her gp again who again prescribed trimethoprim2 three day after that forsythe ’ s husband pete came home to find his wife lying on the sofa shaking unable to call help he rushed her to aampe she wa put on second antibiotic gentamicin and treated sepsis complication of the infection that can be fatal if not treated quickly the gentamicin didn ’ t work either doctor sent forsythe ’ s blood testing but such test can take day bacteria must be grown in culture then tested against multiple antibiotic to find suitable treatment five day after she wa admitted to hospital forsythe wa diagnosed with an infection of multidrug resistant coli and given ertapenem one of the socalled “ last resort ” antibiotics3 it worked but damage from forsythe ’ s episode ha lingered and she life in constant fear of an infection reoccurring six month after her collapse she developed another uti resulting again in hospital stay “ i ’ ve had to accept that i will longer get back to where i wa ” infection she say “ my daughter and son said they felt like they lost their mum because i wasn ’ t who i used to be ” but forsythe wa fortunate sepsis currently kill more people in the uk than lung cancer and the number is growing more of u develop infection immune to antibiotics4 antimicrobial resistance amr – the process of bacteria and yeast and virus evolving defense mechanism against the drug we use to treat them – is progressing so quickly that the un ha called it “ global health emergency ” at least 2 million american contract drugresistant every year socalled “ superbug ” spread rapidly in part because some bacteria are able to borrow resistance gene from neighbouring specie via process called horizontal gene transfer in 2013 researcher in china discovered coli containing mcr1 gene resistant to colistin lastline antibiotic that until recently wa considered too toxic human use colistinresistant infection have now been detected in at least 30 countries5 “ in india and pakistan bangladesh china and country in south america the resistance problem is already endemic ” say colin garner ceo of antibiotic research uk in may 2016 the uk government ’ s review on antimicrobial resistance forecast that by 2050 antibioticresistant infection could kill 10 million people per year – more than all cancer combined6 “ we have good chance of getting to point where lot of people there are effective antibiotic ” daniel berman leader of the global health team at nesta told the threat is difficult to imagine world without antibiotic mean returning to time without organ transplant without hip replacement without many nowroutine surgery it would mean million more woman dying in childbirth make many cancer treatment including chemotherapy impossible and make even the smallest wound potentially lifethreatening berman told “ those of u who are following this closely are actually quite scared ” 7 bacteria are everywhere in our body in the air in the soil coating every surface in their sextillion many bacteria produce antibiotic compound – exactly how many we don ’ t know – probably weapon in microscopic battle resource between different strain of bacteria that ha been going on billion of year because bacteria reproduce so quickly they are able to evolve with astonishing speed introduce bacteria to sufficiently weak concentration of an antibiotic and resistance can emerge within day penicillin resistance wa first documented in 1940 year before it first use in human common misconception is that people can become antibioticresistant they don ’ t – the bacteria dooliver franklinwallissun 24 mar 2019in httpswwwtheguardiancomglobal2019mar24thedrugs dontworkwhathappensafterantibioticsin the text the initialsacronyms gp and aampe stand respectively

casal pretos moravam junto mandava desmandava casa não trabalhando nada vivendo estadão¹ tinhamno visto mourejar² até dentro noite deus havia luar claronos domingo gosto tomar descanso batendo mato dia inteiro sossego espingarda nenhuma nenhuma arma caçar tardinha fazendo parte velhas corocas rezavam terço me santos fugia s léguas viola sanfona qualquer outra qualidade música escuma tristezas coraçãoquase sempre conversando sozinho tam bém maluco diziam porque ignoravam fazia apenas repetir sempre achava preciso fala final padre— “ cada hora vez você háde ter ” — sóe assim passaram menos seis seis ano meio direitinho deste jeito tirar pôr mentira nenhuma porque aqui é estória inventada não é caso acontecido não senhorrosa joão guimarães ficção completa vol 1 rio janeironova fronteira 2017 p 307vocabulário¹estadão luxo²mourejar trabalhar duroconsiderando trajetória protagonista “ hora vez augusto matraga ” correto afirmar fragmento questão referese período

“ formas energéticas tanto hidratos carbono biomassa quanto hidrocarbonetos petróleo demais combustíveis fosseis têm mesma origem radiação solar embora exijam formar períodos tempo diferentesos hidratos carbono formados me açúcares amidos celulose óleos vegetais óleo girassol exemplo lev apenas três me formar armazenado sementes bela flor hidrocarbonetos contrapartida levam centenas milhões ano quantidade energia solar cai hemisfério terra dia equivale ponto vista energético reservas petróleo descobertas incluindo ainda descobertas apenas inferidas ” vasconcelos gilberto felisberto bautista vida jw poder trópicos ed casa amarela 2001 página 254255após leitura excerto lado assinale alternativa correta sobre tema exposto

mr rachel lynde lived just where the avonlea main road dipped down into little hollow fringed with alder and lady ’ eardrop and traversed by brook that had it source away back in the wood of the old cuthbert place it wa reputed to be an intricate headlong brook in it earlier course through those wood with dark secret of pool and cascade but by the time it reached lynde ’ s hollow it wa quiet welloonduoted little stream not even brook could run past mr rachel lynde ’ s door without due regard decency and decorum it probably wa conscious that mr rachel wa sitting at her window keeping sharp eye on everything that passed from brook and child up and that if she noticed anything odd or out of place she would never rest until she had ferreted out the why and wherefore thereofthere are plenty of people in avonlea and out of it who can attend closely to their neighbor ’ s business by dint of neglecting their own but mr rachel lynde wa one of those capable creature who can manage their own concern and those of other folk into the bargain she wa notable housewife her work wa always done and well done she ‘ ran ’ the sewing circle helped run the sundayschool and wa the strongest prop of the church aid society and foreign mission auxiliary yet with all this mr rachel found abundant time to sit hour at her kitchen window knitting ‘ cotton warp ’ quiltsshe had knitted sixteen of them avonlea housekeeper were wont to tell in awed voice and keeping sharp eye on the main road that crossed the hollow and wound up the steep red hill beyond since avonlea occupied little triangular peninsula jutting out into the gulf of st lawrence with water on two side of it anybody who went out of it or into it had to pas over that hill road and so run the unseen gauntlet of mr rachel ’ s allseeing eyesource montgomery lm 1908 anne of green gableshttpswww planetebookcomfreeebooksanneofgreen gablespdf access on april 5th 2019 “ since avonlea occupied little triangular peninsula jutting out into the gulf of st lawrence with water on two side of it anybody who went out of it or into it had to pas over that hill road and so run the unseen gauntlet of mr rachel ’ s allseeing eye ” from this last sentence in the second paragraph we can infer that

the drug don ’ t work what happens after antibioticsantibiotic resistance is growing so fast that routine surgery could soon become impossible but scientist are fighting back in the battle against infection ‘ you essentially trick the bacteria ’ kim lewis one of two researcher who discovered teixobactin photograph adam glanzman1 the first antibiotic that didn ’ t work debbi forsythe wa trimethoprim in march 2016 forsythe genial primary care counsellor from morpeth northumberland contracted urinary tract infection utis are common more than 150 million people worldwide contract one every year so when forsythe saw her gp they prescribed the usual treatment threeday course of antibiotic when few week later she fainted and started passing blood she saw her gp again who again prescribed trimethoprim2 three day after that forsythe ’ s husband pete came home to find his wife lying on the sofa shaking unable to call help he rushed her to aampe she wa put on second antibiotic gentamicin and treated sepsis complication of the infection that can be fatal if not treated quickly the gentamicin didn ’ t work either doctor sent forsythe ’ s blood testing but such test can take day bacteria must be grown in culture then tested against multiple antibiotic to find suitable treatment five day after she wa admitted to hospital forsythe wa diagnosed with an infection of multidrug resistant coli and given ertapenem one of the socalled “ last resort ” antibiotics3 it worked but damage from forsythe ’ s episode ha lingered and she life in constant fear of an infection reoccurring six month after her collapse she developed another uti resulting again in hospital stay “ i ’ ve had to accept that i will longer get back to where i wa ” infection she say “ my daughter and son said they felt like they lost their mum because i wasn ’ t who i used to be ” but forsythe wa fortunate sepsis currently kill more people in the uk than lung cancer and the number is growing more of u develop infection immune to antibiotics4 antimicrobial resistance amr – the process of bacteria and yeast and virus evolving defense mechanism against the drug we use to treat them – is progressing so quickly that the un ha called it “ global health emergency ” at least 2 million american contract drugresistant every year socalled “ superbug ” spread rapidly in part because some bacteria are able to borrow resistance gene from neighbouring specie via process called horizontal gene transfer in 2013 researcher in china discovered coli containing mcr1 gene resistant to colistin lastline antibiotic that until recently wa considered too toxic human use colistinresistant infection have now been detected in at least 30 countries5 “ in india and pakistan bangladesh china and country in south america the resistance problem is already endemic ” say colin garner ceo of antibiotic research uk in may 2016 the uk government ’ s review on antimicrobial resistance forecast that by 2050 antibioticresistant infection could kill 10 million people per year – more than all cancer combined6 “ we have good chance of getting to point where lot of people there are effective antibiotic ” daniel berman leader of the global health team at nesta told the threat is difficult to imagine world without antibiotic mean returning to time without organ transplant without hip replacement without many nowroutine surgery it would mean million more woman dying in childbirth make many cancer treatment including chemotherapy impossible and make even the smallest wound potentially lifethreatening berman told “ those of u who are following this closely are actually quite scared ” 7 bacteria are everywhere in our body in the air in the soil coating every surface in their sextillion many bacteria produce antibiotic compound – exactly how many we don ’ t know – probably weapon in microscopic battle resource between different strain of bacteria that ha been going on billion of year because bacteria reproduce so quickly they are able to evolve with astonishing speed introduce bacteria to sufficiently weak concentration of an antibiotic and resistance can emerge within day penicillin resistance wa first documented in 1940 year before it first use in human common misconception is that people can become antibioticresistant they don ’ t – the bacteria dooliver franklinwallissun 24 mar 2019in httpswwwtheguardiancomglobal2019mar24thedrugsdontworkwhathappensafterantibioticsainda primeiro parágrafo sentença “ utis are common more than 150 million people worldwide contract one every year ” significa 150 milhões pessoas

mr rachel lynde lived just where the avonlea main road dipped down into little hollow fringed with alder and lady ’ eardrop and traversed by brook that had it source away back in the wood of the old cuthbert place it wa reputed to be an intricate headlong brook in it earlier course through those wood with dark secret of pool and cascade but by the time it reached lynde ’ s hollow it wa quiet welloonduoted little stream not even brook could run past mr rachel lynde ’ s door without due regard decency and decorum it probably wa conscious that mr rachel wa sitting at her window keeping sharp eye on everything that passed from brook and child up and that if she noticed anything odd or out of place she would never rest until she had ferreted out the why and wherefore thereofthere are plenty of people in avonlea and out of it who can attend closely to their neighbor ’ s business by dint of neglecting their own but mr rachel lynde wa one of those capable creature who can manage their own concern and those of other folk into the bargain she wa notable housewife her work wa always done and well done she ‘ ran ’ the sewing circle helped run the sundayschool and wa the strongest prop of the church aid society and foreign mission auxiliary yet with all this mr rachel found abundant time to sit hour at her kitchen window knitting ‘ cotton warp ’ quiltsshe had knitted sixteen of them avonlea housekeeper were wont to tell in awed voice and keeping sharp eye on the main road that crossed the hollow and wound up the steep red hill beyond since avonlea occupied little triangular peninsula jutting out into the gulf of st lawrence with water on two side of it anybody who went out of it or into it had to pas over that hill road and so run the unseen gauntlet of mr rachel ’ s allseeing eyesource montgomery lm 1908 anne of green gable httpswww planetebookcomfreeebooksanneofgreen gablespdf access on april 5th 2019the word dipped down alder and eardrop in the very first line of the first paragraph refer to

the following text refers to question 14 and 15 stop wishing you were somewhere elseif you reflect on this insidious tendency to be wishing you were somewhere else you may agree that it ’ s silly even selfdestructive thing to before you jump up and say “ wait minute i don ’ t that ” let explain what i meanthere are many way that we i time wishing we ii somewhere else we ’ ll be at work and wish we iii home or during the middle of the week we iv it were friday sometimes we wish we v something else with our career we wish we vi different responsibility or could spend our time with different people we wish our bos were different or our employee we wish our working environment were different or we had different kind of commute we wish our industry were different or that our circumstance would change this list could obviously go on the problem is these wish aren ’ t reality but rather they are thought of different reality if you ’ re not careful you can begin to wish your life away always wishing you were somewhere other than where you actually are but you ’ re not somewhere else rather you ’ re right here this is reality one of my favorite quote is “ life is what ’ s happening while we ’ re busy making other plan ” slightly different version might be “ life is what ’ s happening while we ’ re wishing we were elsewhere ” when you are wishing you were somewhere else it ’ s almost though you are one step removed from life rather than actually being in it open to life exactly it is from practical standpoint it ’ s very difficult to be focused and effective when your mind is preoccupied with where it would rather be in fact the two are contradiction of term your concentration suffers because there is lack of engagement lack of zeroing in on what ’ s truly significant in addition it ’ s virtually impossible to enjoy yourself and what you are doing when you ’ re focused more on where you ’ d rather be than where you actually are think about the thing you enjoy most in all case they are activity where you are completely absorbed in the moment really focused on what you are doing in the absence of the focus the joy you experience is diminished how much fun is it to read good novel when you ’ re thinking about something elseadapted from don ’ t sweat the small stuff treasury – special collection the officeby richard carlsonthe verb that properly fill in blank i ii iii iv v and vi in the text are

leia texto responder questões números 41 45 “ our child give u strength ” kate and gerrymccann speak about how they continue in search maddmay 01 2014 1053by richard hartleyparkinsonfor educational purpose adapted from httpwwwmirrorcouknewsuknewsmadeleinemccannkategerrysay3481925nearly seven year after maddie disappeared her parent say they have picture of her all over their house so that they will remember her1 almost seven year after madeleine mccann vanished from her family holiday apartment in portugal her parent have spoken about how their other two child provide them with strength2 kate and gerry mccann say that they have photograph of maddie all over their house and keep their child twin sean and amelie who were two at the time up to date with the progress of the police investigation3 speaking to lorraine kelly this morning on itv the couple also spoke about how life them is defined before madeleine disappeared and after4 saturday mark the seventh anniversary since maddie vanished from the flat in praia luz few day before her fourth birthday5 lorraine asked where they get their strength and gerry responded “ i get mine from kate obviously ” 6 kate added “ i think from each other from our child from our family and friend ” 7 gerry said “ we have had unbelievable support not just from those who are close to u but the public support ha been amazing ” 8 he continued “ our life is defined pre and post the abduction unfortunately leading up to portugal having had three very young child and tough two or three year full on and working etc we were just coming through that life seemed good – really good it different now because sean and amelie are really good kid really happy and they bring tremendous amount of joy so it very much we were family of five and now we are functioning family of four ” 9 kate added “ it seven year down the line and we have adapted but still week and month rolling by is still incredibly significant u ” 10 “ whether madeleine had been found after week after six month whether it seven year and one week – thats better than 10 year or whatever so it really significant ” 11 when asked if they will ever give up kate responded “ if we havent found madeleine or we havent found whats happened then we havent done enough there still work to be done ” 12 earlier kate backed revamped alert system triggered when missing child are kidnapped or their life are at risk13 she urged member of the public to sign up child rescue alert which will be overhauled later this month14 she said “ when child is abducted family are devastated and entire community are torn apart the agony of not knowing where your child is is almost impossible to imagine the helplessness is at time overwhelming ” 15 “ but there is now something we can all to help please sign up to receive alert – you could save child ’ s life ” 16 the mother also spoke of how she would prefer to know the truth about what happened to her daughter even if it is “ the worst case scenario ” 17 she added “ but there is always the worst case scenario that ’ s always been possibility and anyone who think that were blinkered doesn ’ t know u ” 18 the new system will allow alert to be issued via text email social medium digital billboard and to the media19 member of the public can already sign up to receive alert although the new system will come into play on international missing child ’ s day on may 2520 child rescue alert wa recently used in the hunt murdered fiveyearold april jones and the system is designed to make the most of the “ golden hour ” when child go missing21 charlie hedge from the national crime agency who helped coordinate the appeal said “ the success of child rescue alert is down to each and every one of u now it ’ s down to the public to sign up the alert so we can send the message widely possible when child go missing ” 22 jo youle chief executive of the charity missing people said “ every minute after their disappearance is crucial to bringing child home safely child rescue alert will now mean the public and company can help – and hopefully save these childrens life ” acordo texto parágrafos 19 20 informam dia 25 maio 2014aserá lançado programa dia internacional crianças desaparecidasbserá lançado programa alerta recuperação criançasccelebrarseá dia internacional crianças desaparecidasdas autoridades discutirão problemas relacionados alerta recuperação criançasetodo mundo acesso doi programasescolha alternativa correta

the following text refers to question 14 and 15stop wishing you were somewhere elseif you reflect on this insidious tendency to be wishing you were somewhere else you may agree that it ’ s silly even selfdestructive thing to before you jump up and say “ wait minute i don ’ t that ” let explain what i meanthere are many way that we i time wishing we ii somewhere else we ’ ll be at work and wish we iii home or during the middle of the week we iv it were friday sometimes we wish we v something else with our career we wish we vi different responsibility or could spend our time with different people we wish our bos were different or our employee we wish our working environment were different or we had different kind of commute we wish our industry were different or that our circumstance would change this list could obviously go on the problem is these wish aren ’ t reality but rather they are thought of different realityif you ’ re not careful you can begin to wish your life away always wishing you were somewhere other than where you actually are but you ’ re not somewhere else rather you ’ re right here this is reality one of my favorite quote is “ life is what ’ s happening while we ’ re busy making other plan ” slightly different version might be “ life is what ’ s happening while we ’ re wishing we were elsewhere ” when you are wishing you were somewhere else it ’ s almost though you are one step removed from life rather than actually being in it open to life exactly it isfrom practical standpoint it ’ s very difficult to be focused and effective when your mind is preoccupied with where it would rather be in fact the two are contradiction of term your concentration suffers because there is lack of engagement lack of zeroing in on what ’ s truly significant in addition it ’ s virtually impossible to enjoy yourself and what you are doing when you ’ re focused more on where you ’ d rather be than where you actually are think about the thing you enjoy most in all case they are activity where you are completely absorbed in the moment really focused on what you are doing in the absence of the focus the joy you experience is diminished how much fun is it to read good novel when you ’ re thinking about something elseadapted from don ’ t sweat the small stuff treasury – specialcollection the officeby richard carlsonaccording to the text

breaking badbreaking bad is an american crime drama television series created and produced by vince gilligan set and produced in albuquerque new mexico breaking bad is the i story of walter white bryan cranston struggling high school chemistry teacher who is diagnosed with ii lung cancer at the beginning of the series he turn to life of crime producing and selling methamphetamine in order to secure his family ’ s financial future before he dy teaming with his former student jesse pinkman aaron paul the series ha been labeled contemporarywestern by it creatorthe series premiered on january 20 2008 in the united state and canada on the cable channel amc and the series finale aired on september 29 2013 breaking bad received iii critical acclaim and is widely regarded one of the greatest television series of all time by it end the series wa among the iv cable show on american television with audience number that doubled in the fifth season from the previous year ’ s episodesbreaking bad wa created by vince gilligan who spent several year writing the fox series the xfiles gilligan wanted to create series in which the protagonist became the antagonist “ television is historically good atkeeping it character in selfimposed stasis so that show can go on year or even decade ” he said “ when i realized this the v next step wa to think how can i show in which the fundamental drive is toward change ” he added that his goal with walter white wa to turn him from mr chip into scarfacewhile gilligan defines the term “ breaking bad ” “ to raise hell ” it apparently mean more than that according to lily rothman it is an old phrase which “ connotes more violence than ‘ raising hell ’ doe the word posse wide variety of nuance to ‘ break bad ’ can mean to ‘ go vi ‘ to ‘ defy authority ’ and break the law to be verbally ‘ combative belligerent or vii or followed by the preposition ‘ on ’ to ‘ completely dominate or humiliate ’ ” the concept emerged gilligan talked with his fellow writer thomas schnauz regarding their viii unemployment and joked that the solution wa them to put “ meth lab in the back of an rv and drive around the country cooking meth and making money ” leia texto responder questões números 25 30urban development – solid waste managementask mayor of developing country city about his or her most pressing problem and solid waste management generally will be high on the list many city solid waste management is their single largest budget item and largest employerit is also critical matter of public health environmental quality quality of life and economic development city that can not effectively manage it waste is rarely able to manage more complex service such health education or transportation and one want to live in city surrounded by garbageas the world urbanizes the situation is becoming more acute more people mean more garbage especially in fastgrowing city where the bulk of waste is generated we estimate that city currently generate roughly 13 billion tonne of solid waste per year with current urbanization trend this figure will grow to 22 billion tonne per year by 2025 – an increase of 70 percentmanaging waste will also become more expensive expenditure that today total 205 billion will grow to 375 billion the cost impact will be most severe in low income country already struggling to meet basic social and infrastructure need particularly their poorest residentsbecause it is such major issue waste management also represents great opportunity city managed well solid waste management practice can reduce greenhouse gas emission level in city including short lived climate pollutant that are far more potent than carbon dioxide city ’ s ability to keep solid waste out of drainage ditch can also influence whether neighborhood flood after heavy stormwwwworldbankorg adaptadode acordo texto aumento produção deresíduos sólidos ocorre principalmente devido

leia texto responder questões 24 30disparity in life span of the rich and the poor isgrowingsabrina tavernisefebruary 12 2016joshua bright the new york timespatients at the free clinic in newton nj researcher debate whether expanding access to health care will shrink the gap in life expectancy between the rich and the poorexperts have long known that rich people generally live longer than poor people but growing body of data show more disturbing pattern despite big advance in medicine technology and education the longevity gap between highincome and lowincome american ha been widening sharplythe poor are losing ground not only in income but also in year of life the most basic measure of wellbeing in the early 1970s 60yearold man in the top half of the earnings ladder could expect to live 12 year longer than man of the same age in the bottom half according to an analysis by the social security administration fastforward to 2001 and he could expect to live 58 year longer than his poorer counterpartnew research released this month contains even more jarring number looking at the extreme end of the income spectrum economist at the brookings institution found that men born in 1920 there wa sixyear difference in life expectancy between the top 10 percent of earner and the bottom 10 percent men born in 1950 that difference had more than doubled to 14 year woman the gap grew to 13 year from 47 year “ there ha been this huge spreading out ” said gary burtless one of the author of the studythe growing chasm is alarming policy maker and ha surfaced in the presidential campaign during democratic debate senator bernie sander and hillary clinton expressed concern over shortening life span some american “ this may be the next frontier of the inequality discussion ” said peter orszag former obama administration official now at citigroup who wa among the first to highlight the pattern the cause are still being investigated but public health researcher say that deep decline in smoking among the affluent and educated may partly explain the differenceoverall according to the brookings study life expectancy the bottom 10 percent of wage earner improved by just 3 percent men born in 1950 compared with those born in 1920 the top 10 percent though it jumped by about 28 percent the researcher used common measure – life expectancy at age 50 – and included data from 1984 to 2012wwwnytimescom adaptadono trecho quarto parágrafo “ shortening life span some american ” expressão “ some american ” contexto refere

leia texto responder questões 24 30disparity in life span of the rich and the poor isgrowingsabrina tavernisefebruary 12 2016joshua bright the new york timespatients at the free clinic in newton nj researcher debate whether expanding access to health care will shrink the gap in life expectancy between the rich and the poorexperts have long known that rich people generally live longer than poor people but growing body of data show more disturbing pattern despite big advance in medicine technology and education the longevity gap between highincome and lowincome american ha been widening sharplythe poor are losing ground not only in income but also in year of life the most basic measure of wellbeing in the early 1970s 60yearold man in the top half of the earnings ladder could expect to live 12 year longer than man of the same age in the bottom half according to an analysis by the social security administration fast forward to 2001 and he could expect to live 58 year longer than his poorer counterpartnew research released this month contains even more jarring number looking at the extreme end of the income spectrum economist at the brookings institution found that men born in 1920 there wa sixyear difference in life expectancy between the top 10 percent of earner and the bottom 10 percent men born in 1950 that difference had more than doubled to 14 year woman the gap grew to 13 year from 47 year “ there ha been this huge spreading out ” said gary burtless one of the author of the studythe growing chasm is alarming policy maker and ha surfaced in the presidential campaign during democratic debate senator bernie sander and hillary clinton expressed concern over shortening life span some american “ this may be the next frontier of the inequality discussion ” said peter orszag former obama administration official now at citigroup who wa among the first to highlight the pattern the cause are still being investigated but public health researcher say that deep decline in smoking among the affluent and educated may partly explain the differenceoverall according to the brookings study life expectancy the bottom 10 percent of wage earner improved by just 3 percent men born in 1950 compared with those born in 1920 the top 10 percent though it jumped by about 28 percentthe researcher used common measure – life expectancy at age 50 – and included data from 1984 to 2012wwwnytimescom adaptadono trecho segundo parágrafo “ not only in income but also in year of life ” expressão “ not only … but also ” indica

leia texto responder questões 24 30disparity in life span of the rich and the poor isgrowingsabrina tavernisefebruary 12 2016experts have long known that rich people generally live longer than poor people but growing body of data show more disturbing pattern despite big advance in medicine technology and education the longevity gap between highincome and lowincome american ha been widening sharplythe poor are losing ground not only in income but also in year of life the most basic measure of wellbeing in the early 1970s 60yearold man in the top half of the earnings ladder could expect to live 12 year longer than man of the same age in the bottom half according to an analysis by the social security administration fast forward to 2001 and he could expect to live 58 year longer than his poorer counterpartnew research released this month contains even more jarring number looking at the extreme end of the income spectrum economist at the brookings institution found that men born in 1920 there wa sixyear difference in life expectancy between the top 10 percent of earner and the bottom 10 percent men born in 1950 that difference had more than doubled to 14 year woman the gap grew to 13 year from 47 year “ there ha been this huge spreading out ” said gary burtless one of the author of the studythe growing chasm is alarming policy maker and ha surfaced in the presidential campaign during democratic debate senator bernie sander and hillary clinton expressed concern over shortening life span some american “ this may be the next frontier of the inequality discussion ” said peter orszag former obama administration official now at citigroup who wa among the first to highlight the pattern the cause are still being investigated but public health researcher say that deep decline in smoking among the affluent and educated may partly explain the differenceoverall according to the brookings study life expectancy the bottom 10 percent of wage earner improved by just leia texto responder questões 24 30disparity in life span of the rich and the poor isgrowingsabrina tavernisefebruary 12 2016joshua bright the new york timespatients at the free clinic in newton nj researcher debate whether expanding access to health care will shrink the gap in life expectancy between the rich and the poorexperts have long known that rich people generally live longer than poor people but growing body of data show more disturbing pattern despite big advance in medicine technology and education the longevity gap between highincome and lowincome american ha been widening sharplythe poor are losing ground not only in income but also in year of life the most basic measure of wellbeing in the early 1970s 60yearold man in the top half of the earnings ladder could expect to live 12 year longer than man of the same age in the bottom half according to an analysis by the social security administration fast forward to 2001 and he could expect to live 58 year longer than his poorer counterpartnew research released this month contains even more jarring number looking at the extreme end of the income spectrum economist at the brookings institution found that men born in 1920 there wa sixyear difference in life expectancy between the top 10 percent of earner and the bottom 10 percent men born in 1950 that difference had more than doubled to 14 year woman the gap grew to 13 year from 47 year “ there ha been this huge spreading out ” said gary burtless one of the author of the studythe growing chasm is alarming policy maker and ha surfaced in the presidential campaign during democratic debate senator bernie sander and hillary clinton expressed concern over shortening life span some american “ this may be the next frontier of the inequality discussion ” said peter orszag former obama administration official now at citigroup who wa among the first to highlight the pattern the cause are still being investigated but public health researcher say that deep decline in smoking among the affluent and educated may partly explain the differenceoverall according to the brookings study life expectancy the bottom 10 percent of wage earner improved by just 3 percent men born in 1950 compared with those born in 1920 the top 10 percent though it jumped by about 28 percent the researcher used common measure – life expectancy at age 50 – and included data from 1984 to 2012wwwnytimescom adaptadoa nova pesquisa brookings institution divulgada

mandaria dar açoutes— é culpa manda fazer filhos fugir perguntou cândido nevesnão maré riso causa filho lá ficara farmácia espera é certo costumava dizer grandes cousas arrastando escrava rua ourives direção alfândega onde residia senhor esquina desta luta cresceu escrava pôs pês parede recuou grande esforço inutilmente alcançou apesar casa próxima gastar tempo lá chegar devera chegou the rolling stone announce free concert in cubathe rolling stone will perform groundbreaking concert in havana cuba on friday march 25 2016 the free concert will take place at the ciudad deportiva la habana and will be the first open air concert in the country by british rock band always exploring new horizon and true pioneer of rock the stone who have toured every corner of the globe will bring their high octane performance and incredible music catalogue to the caribbean the first time everthis onceinalifetime concert event follows the band ’ s america latina ole tour which is currently receiving rave review playing to huge audience in stadium in santiago buenos aire montevideo rio janeiro paulo and porto alegre with lima bogotá and mexico city following next week the band are also leading musician to musician initiative in which much needed musical instrument and equipment are being donated by major supplier the benefit of cuban musician of all genre donor include the gibson foundation vic firth r berkeley pearl zildjian gretsch latin percussion roland and bos with additional assistance from the latin grammy cultural foundationthis historical concert will doubt have mick jagger keith richards charlie watt and ronnie wood mesmerizing new audience of fan with set packed full of classic stone hit well special gem from their million selling albumsthe rolling stone concert which ha been in the planning stage several month come only day after president barack obama ’ s recently announced visit to cubawwwrollingstonescomthe article above explains that

leia texto responder questões 24 30disparity in life span of the rich and the poor isgrowingsabrina tavernisefebruary 12 2016joshua bright the new york timespatients at the free clinic in newton nj researcher debate whether expanding access to health care will shrink the gap in life expectancy between the rich and the poorexperts have long known that rich people generally live longer than poor people but growing body of data show more disturbing pattern despite big advance in medicine technology and education the longevity gap between highincome and lowincome american ha been widening sharplythe poor are losing ground not only in income but also in year of life the most basic measure of wellbeing in the early 1970s 60yearold man in the top half of the earnings ladder could expect to live 12 year longer than man of the same age in the bottom half according to an analysis by the social security administration fast forward to 2001 and he could expect to live 58 year longer than his poorer counterpartnew research released this month contains even more jarring number looking at the extreme end of the income spectrum economist at the brookings institution found that men born in 1920 there wa sixyear difference in life expectancy between the top 10 percent of earner and the bottom 10 percent men born in 1950 that difference had more than doubled to 14 year woman the gap grew to 13 year from 47 year “ there ha been this huge spreading out ” said gary burtless one of the author of the studythe growing chasm is alarming policy maker and ha surfaced in the presidential campaign during democratic debate senator bernie sander and hillary clinton expressed concern over shortening life span some american “ this may be the next frontier of the inequality discussion ” said peter orszag former obama administration official now at citigroup who wa among the first to highlight the pattern the cause are still being investigated but public health researcher say that deep decline in smoking among the affluent and educated may partly explain the differenceoverall according to the brookings study life expectancy the bottom 10 percent of wage earner improved by just 3 percent men born in 1950 compared with those born in 1920 the top 10 percent though it jumped by about 28 percent the researcher used common measure – life expectancy at age 50 – and included data from 1984 to 2012wwwnytimescom adaptadono trecho quinto parágrafo “ the top 10 percent though it jumped by about 28 percent ” termo destaque pode substituído alteração sentido

campaignhospitalvisitnormanlambandyburnhampoliticians commit to john ’ s campaign to allow people 24hour hospital access to vulnerable patient with dementia following deluge of support1 – campaign to allow friend and family open access to people with dementia while they are in hospital ha seen significant victory this weekend with backing from senior politician the observerbacked campaign ha won the support of health minister norman lamb who ha promised to write to all nh trust promoting the idea while the shadow health secretary andy burnham ha committed to strengthening the nh constitution on the issue and including it in labour ’ s election manifestothe shadow health secretary andy burnham will include the issue in labour election manifesto photograph christopher thomond2 – “ i could have wept with gratitude and relief ” said novelist nicci gerrard whose experience with her father ’ s hospital care led her to launch john ’ s campaign it call the family and carers of people with dementia to be allowed to remain with them in hospital many hour of the day and night necessary the campaign ha been deluged with support not only from family but from doctor nurse and charity working with people with dementia several nh trust have agreed to start implementing change within their own hospital and letting staff know what is expected of them3 – gerrard said crossparty support showed it wa not political issue but one of common sense and compassion it is she writes in the observer today “ rare instance where the cost in both financial and human term are none and the benefit enormous ” 4 – more than quarter of hospital bed in the uk are now occupied by people with dementia third will never return to their own home and just under half will leave hospital in worse condition than when they entered gerrard ’ s father dr john gerrard who wa diagnosed with alzheimer ’ s in his 70 deteriorated significantly during his hospital stay last year something his family felt could have been avoided had they been allowed to spend more time supporting him while he wa there5 – the campaigner backed by labour mp valerie vaz among others believe the current nh advice to parent with child in hospital that they should stay with their child much possible should also apply to people with dementia who are often vulnerable and very easily distressed6 – on wednesday which is nh change day – chance positive change at grassroots level to be highlighted more widely – nh england is organizing what it is calling “ thunderclap ” on behalf of john ’ s campaign across thousand of social medium account including twitter and facebook at 11amlendo título subtítulos 1º parágrafo texto escolha alternativa apresenta somente apoiadores campanha

cena v – jorge madalena mariajorge – os deus nesta casa maria beijalhe escapulário1 mão madalena somente escapuláriomadalena – sejais bemvindo irmãomaria – boa tardes tio jorgejorge – senhora mana bênção deus cubra filha desassossegado vós mana madalena aflijais espero nada certo uma notícias lisboamadalena assustada – poi foijorge – nada assusteis bom estejais prevenida volo digo governadores querem sair cidade capricho verdadeiro aturarem metidos ali dentro toda força peste agora pode dizer acabada raríssimos casos força querem mudar aresmadalena – poi coitadosmaria – coitado povo valem vidas pestes desgraças assim entendia governasse serviço deus rei mandava ficar última onde miséria perigo maior atender remédio amparo necessitados poi rei quer dizer pai comum todosjorge – donzela teodora assim filha mundo doutro modo faremosmaria – emendálojorge madalena baixo – sabeis medo desta criançamadalena modo – eujorge alto – enfim resolveram sair sabereis corte “ buen retiro ” cinco real senhores governadores portugal d filipe castela deus guarde escolhida boa vila almada deveu fama águas sadias are lavados graciosa vistamadalena – deixálos virjorge – assim remédio ouvi resto pobre convento paulo hospedar senhor arcebispo d miguel castro presidente governo bom prelado tira humilde sossego vida vir senhor príncipe secular paciência pior vosso casomadalena – meujorge – vosso manuel sousa porque outros quatro governadores – aqui mandaram dizer segredo lisboa – dizem querem vir casa pôr aqui aposentadoria2maria vivacidade – fechamoslhes porta metemos gente dentro – terço3 pai seiscentos homens – defendemonos poi tirania bonito tomara ver pareça batalhajorge – louquinhamadalena – mal fizemos conde sabugal outros governadores fazerem desacato aí outras casas sabem nesta the new york timesganhar dinheiro fazer bemem colaboração comfolha spaulo 9 maio 2015algumas pessoas vão trabalhar setores pagam bem financeiro terem estilo vida inclui mansões carros velozes hoje dia porém faça esperança ajudar sociedade si mesmoo movimento chamado “ altruísmo eficaz ” membros matt wage sobre colunista “ nyt ” nicholas kristof escreveuna universidade princeton nova jersey wage destacava filosofia conhecido pensar dever fazer algo tornar mundo lugar melhor formar 2012 trabalhar firma corretagem arbitragem financeiraseu raciocínio ganhar dinheiro chance mudar vida outras pessoas melhor 2013 wage doou u 100 mil r 300 mil fin beneficentes – menos metade renda bruta revelou “ nyt ” disse pretendia continuar trabalhar setor financeiro doar metade recebiauma entidades beneficia doações against malaria foundation consta consegue salvar vida criança cada u 3340 r 10020 doadoskristof escreveu “ tudo sugere wage talvez salve vidas doações salvaria tornado funcionário ong ” kristof observou abordagem wage pode questionada doar parte salário bastanteexistem causa merecedoras ajuda outras realmente correto aceitar emprego dinheiro “ sei funcionaria todos ” escreveu aplaudiu prática maneira geral existem outras maneiras alcançar metas semelhantes chamado “ investimento impacto ” prática usar capital “ produzir bem fornecer serviço cause impacto social positivo tempo gera algum nível retorno financeiro ” definição saiu livro “ impact investment ” keith allman deutsche bank ximea escobar nogales diretora gestão impacto firma private equityo livro explica envolverse setor investimento impacto desde analisar missão empresa determinar ponto êxito alcançar meta manterse rentávelo professor economia harvard sendhil mullainathan espera estudantes sintam atraídos altruísmo tornem simple “ pessoas buscam receita ” escrevendo “ nyt ” notou quase 20 alunos trabalhar formar harvard 2014 setor financeiroele vê maus olhos desejo bons empregos questiona “ decisão boa sociedade ” mullainathan escreveu todo trabalho possui potencial beneficiar sociedade “ advogado ajuda redigir contratos precisos pode beneficiar bom funcionamento comércio desse modo gera riqueza ” setor financeiro pode melhorar vida pessoas comuns ajudandoas poupar dinheiro faculdade filhos oferecendo seguros pequenos produtores agrícolas possibilitando pessoas conseguir financiamentos imobiliários prestações viáveispara alunos optam trabalhar setor financeiro mullainathan disse “ espero percebam têm potencial fazer bem apenas ganhar dinheiro ” te felderqual trechos abaixo apresenta relação causa consequência
