oxfam study find richest 1 is likely to control half of global wealth by 2016by patricia cohenjanuary 19 2015the richest 1 percent is likely to control more than half of the globe ’ s total wealth by next year the antipoverty charity oxfam reported in study released on monday the warning about deepening global inequality come just the world ’ s business elite prepare to meet this week at the annual world economic forum in davos switzerlandthe 80 wealthiest people in the world altogether own 19 trillion the report found nearly the same amount shared by the 35 billion people who occupy the bottom half of the world ’ s income scale last year it took 85 billionaire to equal that figure and the richest 1 percent of the population control nearly half of the world ’ s total wealth share that is also increasingthe type of inequality that currently characterizes the world ’ s economy is unlike anything seen in recent year the report explained “ between 2002 and 2010 the total wealth of the poorest half of the world in current u dollar had been increasing more or le at the same rate that of billionaire ” it said “ however since 2010 it ha been decreasing over that time ” winnie byanyima the charity ’ s executive director noted in statement that more than billion people lived on le than 125 day “ we really want to live in world where the 1 percent own more than the rest of u combined ” m byanyima said “ the scale of global inequality is quite simply staggering ” investor with interest in finance insurance and health saw the biggest windfall oxfam said using data from forbes magazine ’ s list of billionaire it said those listed having interest in the pharmaceutical and health care industry saw their net worth jump by 47 percent the charity credited those individual ’ rapidly growing fortune campaign to protect and enhance their interest to multimilliondollar in part lobbyingwwwnytimescom adaptadono contexto último parágrafo sentido termo “ windfall ” “ investor with interest in finance insurance and health saw the biggest windfall ” equivale português

oxfam study find richest 1 is likely to control half of global wealth by 2016by patricia cohenjanuary 19 2015the world ’ s business elite will meet this week at the annual world economic forum in davos switzerland credit jean christophe botteuropean pressphoto agencythe richest 1 percent is likely to control more than half of the globe ’ s total wealth by next year the antipoverty charity oxfam reported in study released on monday the warning about deepening global inequality come just the world ’ s business elite prepare to meet this week at the annual world economic forum in davos switzerlandthe 80 wealthiest people in the world altogether own 19 trillion the report found nearly the same amount shared by the 35 billion people who occupy the bottom half of the world ’ s income scale last year it took 85 billionaire to equal that figure and the richest 1 percent of the population control nearly half of the world ’ s total wealth share that is also increasingthe type of inequality that currently characterizes the world ’ s economy is unlike anything seen in recent year the report explained “ between 2002 and 2010 the total wealth of the poorest half of the world in current u dollar had been increasing more or le at the same rate that of billionaire ” it said “ however since 2010 it ha been decreasing over that time ” winnie byanyima the charity ’ s executive director noted in statement that more than billion people lived on le than 125 day “ we really want to live in world where the 1 percent own more than the rest of u combined ” m byanyima said “ the scale of global inequality is quite simply staggering ” investor with interest in finance insurance and health saw the biggest windfall oxfam said using data from forbes magazine ’ s list of billionaire it said those listed having interest in the pharmaceutical and health care industry saw their net worth jump by 47 percent the charity credited those individual ’ rapidly growing fortune campaign to protect and enhance their interest to multimilliondollar in part lobbyingwwwnytimescom adaptadono trecho terceiro parágrafo “ however since 2010 it ha been decreasing over that time ” termo “ however ” pode substituído alteração sentido

cena v – jorge madalena mariajorge – os deus nesta casamaria beijalhe escapulário1 mão madalena somente escapuláriomadalena – sejais bemvindo irmãomaria – boa tardes tio jorgejorge – senhora mana bênção deus cubra filha desassossegado vós mana madalena aflijais espero nada certo uma notícias lisboamadalena assustada – poi foijorge – nada assusteis bom estejais prevenida volo digo governadores querem sair cidade capricho verdadeiro aturarem metidos ali dentro toda força peste agora pode dizer acabada raríssimos casos força querem mudar aresmadalena – poi coitadosmaria – coitado povo valem vidas pestes desgraças assim entendia governasse serviço deus rei mandava ficar última onde miséria perigo maior atender remédio amparo necessitados poi rei quer dizer pai comum todosjorge – donzela teodora assim filha mundo doutro modo faremosmaria – emendálojorge madalena baixo – sabeis medo desta criançamadalena modo – eujorge alto – enfim resolveram sair sabereis corte “ buen retiro ” cinco real senhores governadores portugal d filipe castela deus guarde escolhida boa vila almada deveu fama águas sadias are lavados graciosa vistamadalena – deixálos virjorge – assim remédio ouvi resto pobre convento paulo hospedar senhor arcebispo d miguel castro presidente governo bom prelado tira humilde sossego vida vir senhor príncipe secular paciência pior vosso casomadalena – meujorge – vosso manuel sousa porque outros quatro governadores – aqui mandaram dizer segredo lisboa – dizem querem vir casa pôr aqui aposentadoria2maria vivacidade – fechamoslhes porta metemos gente dentro – terço3 pai seiscentos homens – defendemonos poi tirania bonito tomara ver pareça batalhajorge – louquinhamadalena – mal fizemos conde sabugal outros governadores fazerem desacato aí outras casas sabem nesta senhoras família aquiteatro vol 3 18441 escapulário faixa tecido frades freiras certas ordens religiosas cristãs usam pendente sobre peito2 pôr aposentadoria ficar morar3 terço corpo tropas exércitos português espanhol séculos xvi xviifocalizando eventos final século xvi início século xvii português passagem procura destacar

oxfam study find richest 1 is likely to controlhalf of global wealth by 2016by patricia cohenjanuary 19 2015the world ’ s business elite will meet this week at the annualworld economic forum in davos switzerland credit jeanchristophe botteuropean pressphoto agencythe richest 1 percent is likely to control more than half of the globe ’ s total wealth by next year the antipoverty charity oxfam reported in study released on monday the warning about deepening global inequality come just the world ’ s business elite prepare to meet this week at the annual world economic forum in davos switzerlandthe 80 wealthiest people in the world altogether own 19 trillion the report found nearly the same amount shared by the 35 billion people who occupy the bottom half of the world ’ s income scale last year it took 85 billionaire to equal that figure and the richest 1 percent of the population control nearly half of the world ’ s total wealth share that is also increasingthe type of inequality that currently characterizes the world ’ s economy is unlike anything seen in recent year the report explained “ between 2002 and 2010 the total wealth of the poorest half of the world in current u dollar had been increasing more or le at the same rate that of billionaire ” it said “ however since 2010 it ha been decreasing over that time ” winnie byanyima the charity ’ s executive director noted in statement that more than billion people lived on le than 125 day “ we really want to live in world where the 1 percent own more than the rest of u combined ” m byanyima said “ the scale of global inequality is quite simply staggering ” investor with interest in finance insurance and health saw the biggest windfall oxfam said using data from forbes magazine ’ s list of billionaire it said those listed having interest in the pharmaceutical and health care industry saw their net worth jump by 47 percent the charity credited those individual ’ rapidly growing fortune in part to multimilliondollar lobbying campaign to protect and enhance their interestswwwnytimescom adaptadoa partir informações apresentadas sobre relatório oxfam resposta esperada winnie byanyima pergunta “ we really want to live in world where the 1 percent own more than the rest of u combined ”

new zealand pizza chain aim to become the world first company to offer commercial drone delivery service milestone in the once unthinkable quest to save time and money with an airborne supply chain dispensing with people domino ’ s pizza enterprise ltd conducted demonstration pizza delivery by drone in the new zealand city of auckland on thursday and afterwards said it aimed to be the first company to launch regular drone service late this year despite the fact that domino ’ s chief executive officer don meij had said in statement “ we ’ ve always said that it doesn ’ t make sense to have 2tonne machine delivering 2kilogram order ” even though domino ’ s pizza used in it test drone provided by u headquarted australian drone company flirtey philip solaris director of new zealand based drone company called xcraft enterprise said that while new zealand ha accommodating regulation on drone domino ’ s would be held back by rule requiring drone to be kept in sight at all time and added “ i cant truly see how commercially viable that idea is because you would have to literally have somebody walking along to keep it in the line of sight watching it at all time ” other than that he warned that “ domino ’ s service would still need to overcome random hazard like power line moving vehicle child in the backyard playing ” httpwwwreuterscomarticleusnewzealanddronesfoodiduskcn1100h0 acessado 12012017adaptado fin educacionaisassinale alternativa cuja informação encontra texto

leia texto abaixo responda questões 37 38a new zealand pizza chain aim to become the world first company to offer commercial drone delivery service milestone in the once unthinkable quest to save time and money with an airborne supply chain dispensing with people domino ’ s pizza enterprise ltd conducted demonstration pizza delivery by drone in the new zealand city of auckland on thursday and afterwards said it aimed to be the first company to launch regular drone service late this year despite the fact that domino ’ s chief executive officer don meij had said in statement “ we ’ ve always said that it doesn ’ t make sense to have 2tonne machine delivering 2kilogram order ” even though domino ’ s pizza used in it test drone provided by u headquarted australian drone company flirtey philip solaris director of new zealand based drone company called xcraft enterprise said that while new zealand ha accommodating regulation on drone domino ’ s would be held back by rule requiring drone to be kept in sight at all time and added “ i cant truly see how commercially viable that idea is because you would have to literally have somebody walking along to keep it in the line of sight watching it at all time ” other than that he warned that “ domino ’ s service would still need to overcome random hazard like power line moving vehicle child in the backyard playing ” httpwwwreuterscomarticleusnewzealanddronesfood iduskcn1100h0 acessado 12012017 adaptado fin educacionaisno texto grupo palavras “ rule requiring drone to be kept in sight at all time ” segundo parágrafo melhor representado português palavras

pompeia pauloem projeção roberta carvalhoem janeiro 2016 folha anunciou estreia blog voltado discussão questões gênero chamado empoderamento feminino nascido movimento agora mulheres ocuparam espaço colunistas homens jornais blog homônimo somava dezenas outros interpretei saudável oferta novos temas leitores jornal neste espaço alertara tempo redes sociais turbulentas sinalizavam hora reinventar páginas opinião contabilizava agosto 2016 32 mulheres 130 colunistas jornalna madrugada sexta 31 março agora publicou post potencial arrebatador redes sociais post “ josé mayer assediou ” colocado ar 0h45nele figurinista susllem tonani acusava ator têla assediado durante oito me tv globo manhã texto lido ompartilhado redes sociais volta 10h folha tirouo ar dar explicaçãocobrei jornal crítica interna circula torno 12h30 obrigação prestar satisfação leitor 14h22 publicada justificativa sumiço post conteúdo retirado ar porque desrespeitou princípio editorial folha publicar acusação após ouvir registrar argumentos parte acusada salvo casos possívelàs 17h30 texto voltou ficar disponível tempo publicada reportagem resumia acusações figurinista ouvia ator negava havia sido imputado tv globo dizia comentar assuntos internos assegurava haveria apuração rigorosa ouvidos todos envolvidos busca verdadehouve mobilização funcionárias emissora culminou manifesto cujo título tornaria emble mático camisetas post mexeu mexeu toda três dia post original emissora divulgou decisão suspender josé mayerem carta ator assumiu ter errado pediu desculpas tropeçou resumir episódio brincadeira tentar dividir culpa geração homens acima 60 ano vítimas catequese única perversaa polêmica alcançou topo redes sociais chegando dez assuntos comentados mundo twitter retirada ar post folha explicação imediata deixando rastros digitais gerou reclamações suscitou elaboração conjecturasacredito folha precisa explicar motivou retirada compactuando operação abafa parte globo apurou erros relato registrou leitoro editorexecutivo folha sérgio dávila diz direção surpreendida conteúdo determinou retirada temporária outro lado ouvido nesse intervalo reportagem publicada explicar havia acontecido portanto qualquer explicação afirmapara dávila caso concreto havia impeditivo procedimentopadrão ouvir outro lado respeitadoa folha hoje 124 colunistas 48 blog grande parte leitores diferencia un outros estrutura interna jornal blogueiros colunistas tratados forma diferenciada todos colunistas lido editores secretários redação ante textos publicadosos blog acompanhados posteriori própria natureza diário modalidade comporta autores cuidam diretamente publicação textosargumenta dávila todos escrevem folha incluindo blogueiros devem submeter quaisquer acusa ções prática ilegal editores ante publicálasé dever titulares blog feminino feminista trazer público sabendo verdadeira denúncia prática machista dever jornal trabalhar tal informação dar voz àquele acusado quer sejao correto sido publicação texto original blog remissão simultânea reportagem produzida corpo editorial folha submetida padrões exigidos manual redação isenção transparência equilíbrio retirada ar explicitou falhas comunicação procedimentoum poderoso machão sucumbiu tempo outros leitora entanto lembrou ombudsman nesta semana ilustrada ganhou três novos colunistas humor dividirão espaço consagrado josé simão todos homens mulheres exemplo quadrado charge página 2 folhapaula cesarino costaombudsman expressão origem sueca significa representante cidadão palavra formada união ombuds representante man ho mem termo surgiu 1809 países escan dinavos designar ouvidorgeral parlamento respon sável mediar tentar solucionar reclamações população junto governohoje dia ombudsman transformou profissão presente quase toda grandes médias empresas públicas privadasa função búds conhecidos enxergar problemas pontos negativos determinada empresa instituição partir ótica consumi dorcidadão tentar solucionar crisis maneira imparcialdentro imprensa ombudsman intermediador editoria jornal exemplo leitores estados unidos função ombudsman surgiu ano 1960 brasil cargo existe desde 1989 jornal folha s paulo publicou primeira editoria ombudsman ficaria responsável portavoz leitores solucionando transmitindo reclamações jornalem muitas empresas ombudsman ligado departa mento serviços jurídicosdisponível httpswwwsignificadoscombrombudsmanacesso 13 maio 2017 adaptado fin vestibularainda relação trecho mencionado questãoanterior feminino feminista remetemse respectivamente blog

leia texto responder questões 11 20breaking down barriersshuffling foot and the general buzz of conversation made lecture trial gemma long during her first degree she suffers from sensory overload connected to her autism which wa only diagnosed after she graduated but when she started teachertraining course year later she received access to software to help her cope with dyslexia and found it transformative “ i struggled to understand the point of lecture until i got that software ” recall long “ i didn ’ t realise how much useful information wa in them someone who is hypersensitive to noise i spend most of my time in lecture trying to filter out the background noise which mean i miss much of what the lecturer is saying being able to audio record the lecture and listen back to them in silent room meant i wa finally able to digest the content ” technology is breaking down barrier faced by student with disability online journal article now mean that those with visual impairment can zoom in to read printed text or convert it to easiertoread format such braille university are also increasingly recording lecture which student can replay at their own pace which benefit student with dyslexia or attention deficit disorder tooaccording to alistair mcnaught digital learning consultant university are increasingly tracking how student learn and then directing them to the accessible resource most suited to their personal need mcnaught appreciates the way assistive technology can help all student — whether they have disability or not — but stress that it ’ s important university to get the basic right first “ many higher and further institution have inaccessible website or inaccessible digital content if the content is inaccessible investment in assistive technology can be undermined at stroke ” “ university just need to get better at promoting the support that ’ s already there ” say gemma long “ making specialist software and training generally available rather than confining it to disabled student make it more widely known well remove stigma ” someone like her who received her diagnosis late it would have been particularly helpful to this end the assistive technology network she founded to represent staff who support their disabled student with tech will hold it first award ceremony next monthuniversities are slowly tackling the barrier disabled student there ’ s more yet to come the prospect of virtual reality – particularly when it come to fieldwork “ it can be incredibly difficult disabled student to get wheelchair on to salt marsh ” say pier wilkinson researcher in the area “ but if the learning aim are being immersed in an environment and making discovery virtual reality an achieve that ” wwwtheguardiancom 03062019 adaptadothe term “ tackling ” in the first sentence of the last paragraph mean

leia texto responder questões 11 20breaking down barriersshuffling foot and the general buzz of conversation made lecture trial gemma long during her first degree she suffers from sensory overload connected to her autism which wa only diagnosed after she graduated but when she started teachertraining course year later she received access to software to help her cope with dyslexia and found it transformative “ i struggled to understand the point of lecture until i got that software ” recall long “ i didn ’ t realise how much useful information wa in them someone who is hypersensitive to noise i spend most of my time in lecture trying to filter out the background noise which mean i miss much of what the lecturer is saying being able to audio record the lecture and listen back to them in silent room meant i wa finally able to digest the content ” technology is breaking down barrier faced by student with disability online journal article now mean that those with visual impairment can zoom in to read printed text or convert it to easiertoread format such braille university are also increasingly recording lecture which student can replay at their own pace which benefit student with dyslexia or attention deficit disorder tooaccording to alistair mcnaught digital learning consultant university are increasingly tracking how student learn and then directing them to the accessible resource most suited to their personal need mcnaught appreciates the way assistive technology can help all student — whether they have disability or not — but stress that it ’ s important university to get the basic right first “ many higher and further institution have inaccessible website or inaccessible digital content if the content is inaccessible investment in assistive technology can be undermined at stroke ” “ university just need to get better at promoting the support that ’ s already there ” say gemma long “ making specialist software and training generally available rather than confining it to disabled student make it more widely known well remove stigma ” someone like her who received her diagnosis late it would have been particularly helpful to this end the assistive technology network she founded to represent staff who support their disabled student with tech will hold it first award ceremony next monthuniversities are slowly tackling the barrier disabled student there ’ s more yet to come the prospect of virtual reality – particularly when it come to fieldwork “ it can be incredibly difficult disabled student to get wheelchair on to salt marsh ” say pier wilkinson researcher in the area “ but if the learning aim are being immersed in an environment and making discovery virtual reality an achieve that ” wwwtheguardiancom 03062019 can zoom in to read printed text or convert it to easiertoread format such braille university are also increasingly recording lecture which student can replay at their own pace which benefit student with dyslexia or attention deficit disorder tooaccording to alistair mcnaught digital learning consultant university are increasingly tracking how student learn and then directing them to the accessible resource most suited to their personal need mcnaught appreciates the way assistive technology can help all student — whether they have disability or not — but stress that it ’ s important university to get the basic right first “ many higher and further institution have inaccessible website or inaccessible digital content if the content is inaccessible investment in assistive technology can be undermined at stroke ” “ university just need to get better at promoting the support that ’ s already there ” say gemma long “ making specialist software and training generally available rather than confining it to disabled student make it more widely known well remove stigma ” someone like her who received her diagnosis late it would have been particularly helpful to this end the assistive technology network she founded to represent staff who support their disabled student with tech will hold it first award ceremony next monthuniversities are slowly tackling the barrier disabled student there ’ s more yet to come the prospect of virtual reality – particularly when it come to fieldwork “ it can be incredibly difficult disabled student to get wheelchair on to salt marsh ” say pier wilkinson researcher in the area “ but if the learning aim are being immersed in an environment and making discovery virtual reality an achieve that ” wwwtheguardiancom 03062019 implication student with disability the u supreme court ruled wednesday that school must provide higher educational standard child with special need school must more than provide ‘ merely more than minimis ’ education student with disability and instead must provide them with an opportunity to make “ appropriately ambitious ” progress in line with the federal education law “ when all is said and done ” wrote chief justice john g robert “ student offered an education program providing ‘ merely more than minimis ’ progress from year to year can hardly be said to have been offered an education at all ” he continued citing 1982 supreme court ruling on special education “ child with disability receiving an instruction that aim so low would be equivalent to ‘ sitting idly awaiting the time when they were old enough to drop out ’ ” there are roughly 64 million student with disability between age 3 to 21 representing roughly 13 percent of all student according to institute education statistic each year 300000 of those student leave school and just 65 percent of student with disability complete high schoolthe case which culminated in the supreme court decision originated with an autistic boy in colorado named endrew his parent pulled him out of school in 5th grade because they disagreed with his individualized education plan under federal law the individual with disability education act idea school must work with family to develop individualized learning plan student with disabilitieswhile endrew had been making progress in the public school his parent felt his plan that year simply replicated goal from year past result they enrolled him in private school where they argued endrew made academic and social progressseeking tuition reimbursement they filed complaint with the state ’ s department of education in which they argued that endrew had been denied “ free appropriate public education ” the school district won the suit and when his parent filed lawsuit in federal district court the judge also sided with the school district in the supreme court case endrew and his family asked clarification about the type of education benefit the federal law requires of school specifically whether it requires ‘ merely more than minimis ’ or something greater “ the idea demand more ” robert wrote in the opinion “ it requires an educational program reasonably calculated to enable child to make progress appropriate in light of the child ’ s circumstance ” reimbursement sum paid to cover money that ha been spent or lostinlthttpswwwusnewscomnewseducationnewsarticles20170322supremecourtexpandsrights forstudentswithdisabilitiesgt 30032018no excerto sexto parágrafo “ whether it requires ‘ merely more than minimis ’ or something greater ” palavra it refere

leia texto responder questões 16 20unexpected effect of nutritionin the late 1960s team of researcher began distributing nutritional supplement to family with young child in rural guatemala they were testing the assumption that providing enough protein in the first few year of life would reduce the incidence of stunted growthit did child who received added nutrition grew 1 to 2 centimetre taller than those in control group but the benefit didn ’ t stop there these child went on to score higher on reading and knowledge test adolescent and when researcher returned in the early 2000s woman who had received the supplement in the first three year of life completed more year of schooling and men had higher income “ had there not been these followup this study probably would have been largely forgotten ” say reynaldo martorell specialist in maternal and child nutrition who led the followup study instead he say the finding made financial institution such the world bank think of early nutritional intervention longterm investment in human health since the guatemalan research study around the world — in brazil peru jamaica the philippine kenya and zimbabwe — have all associated poor or stunted growth in young child with lower cognitive test score and worse school achievement picture slowly emerged that being too short early in life is sign of adverse condition — such poor diet and regular episode of diarrhea — and predictor intellectual deficit and mortalitycarina storrs wwwnaturecom 12072017 adaptadoas far the result of the study are concerned we understand that

unexpected effect of nutritionin the late 1960s team of researcher began distributing nutritional supplement to family with young child in rural guatemala they were testing the assumption that providing enough protein in the first few year of life would reduce the incidence of stunted growthit did child who received added nutrition grew 1 to 2 centimetre taller than those in control group but the benefit didn ’ t stop there these child went on to score higher on reading and knowledge test adolescent and when researcher returned in the early 2000s woman who had received the supplement in the first three year of life completed more year of schooling and men had higher income “ had there not been these followup this study probably would have been largely forgotten ” say reynaldo martorell specialist in maternal and child nutrition who led the followup study instead he say the finding made financial institution such the world bank think of early nutritional intervention longterm investment in human health since the guatemalan research study around the world — in brazil peru jamaica the philippine kenya and zimbabwe — have all associated poor or stunted growth in young child with lower cognitive test score and worse school achievement picture slowly emerged that being too short early in life is sign of adverse condition — such poor diet and regular episode of diarrhea — and predictor intellectual deficit and mortalitycarina storrs wwwnaturecom 12072017 adaptadode acordo terceiro parágrafo relevante particularidade pesquisa descrita recai sobre fato

supreme court expands right student with disabilitiesby lauren camera education reporter – march 22 2017 adaptadoin unanimous decision with major implication student with disability the u supreme court ruled wednesday that school must provide higher educational standard child with special need school must more than provide ‘ merely more than minimis ’ education student with disability and instead must provide them with an opportunity to make “ appropriately ambitious ” progress in line with the federal education law “ when all is said and done ” wrote chief justice john g robert “ student offered an education program providing ‘ merely more than minimis ’ progress from year to year can hardly be said to have been offered an education at all ” he continued citing 1982 supreme court ruling on special education “ child with disability receiving an instruction that aim so low would be equivalent to ‘ sitting idly awaiting the time when they were old enough to drop out ’ ” there are roughly 64 million student with disability between age 3 to 21 representing roughly 13 percent of all student according to institute education statistic each year 300000 of those student leave school and just 65 percent of student with disability complete high schoolthe case which culminated in the supreme court decision originated with an autistic boy in colorado named endrew his parent pulled him out of school in 5th grade because they disagreed with his individualized education plan under federal law the individual with disability education act idea school must work with family to develop individualized learning plan student with disabilitieswhile endrew had been making progress in the public school his parent felt his plan that year simply replicated goal from year past result they enrolled him in private school where they argued endrew made academic and social progressseeking tuition reimbursement they filed complaint with the state ’ s department of education in which they argued that endrew had been denied “ free appropriate public education ” the school district won the suit and when his parent filed lawsuit in federal district court the judge also sided with the school district in the supreme court case endrew and his family asked clarification about the type of education benefit the federal law requires of school specifically whether it requires ‘ merely more than minimis ’ or something greater “ the idea demand more ” robert wrote in the opinion “ it requires an educational program reasonably calculated to enable child to make progress appropriate in light of the child ’ s circumstance ” reimbursement sum paid to cover money that ha been spent or lostinlthttpswwwusnewscomnewseducationnewsarticles20170322supremecourtexpandsrightsforstudentswithdisabilitiesgt 30032018o fato levou publicação deste texto março 2017

unexpected effect of nutritionin the late 1960s team of researcher began distributing nutritional supplement to family with young child in rural guatemala they were testing the assumption that providing enough protein in the first few year of life would reduce the incidence of stunted growthit did child who received added nutrition grew 1 to 2 centimetre taller than those in control group but the benefit didn ’ t stop there these child went on to score higher on reading and knowledge test adolescent and when researcher returned in the early 2000s woman who had received the supplement in the first three year of life completed more year of schooling and men had higher income “ had there not been these followup this study probably would have been largely forgotten ” say reynaldo martorell specialist in maternal and child nutrition who led the followup study instead he say the finding made financial institution such the world bank think of early nutritional intervention longterm investment in human health since the guatemalan research study around the world — in brazil peru jamaica the philippine kenya and zimbabwe — have all associated poor or stunted growth in young child with lower cognitive test score and worse school achievement picture slowly emerged that being too short early in life is sign of adverse condition — such poor diet and regular episode of diarrhea — and predictor intellectual deficit and mortalitycarina storrs wwwnaturecom 12072017 adaptadowhat according to the third paragraph can work predictor intellectual deficit and mortality
